The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE TVVENTIE THIRD PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: VerÅ¿e 1 THe Lord is my Shepheard; I Å¿hall not want.
VerÅ¿e 2 Hee maketh me to lye downe in greene paÅ¿tures; he leadeth me beÅ¿ide the Å¿till waters.
VerÅ¿e 3 Hee reÅ¿toreth my Å¿oule; hee leadeth mee in the paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, for his Names Å¿ake.
VerÅ¿e 4 Yea, though I walke through the Valley of the Å¿hadow of death; I will feare no evill: for Thou art with mee; Thy rod and thy Å¿taffe, they comfort mee.

VerÅ¿e 5 Thou prepareÅ¿t a Table before me, in the preÅ¿ence
of mine enemies; Thou anoynteÅ¿t my head with Oyle; my cup runneth over.
VerÅ¿e 6 Surely, goodneÅ¿Å¿e, and mercy, Å¿hall follow me, all the dayes of my life; and I will dwell in the houÅ¿e of the Lord for ever.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE XXIII. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
IS it not a grievous fall, that VerÅ¿e 1 where I might have Å¿aid; The Lord is my Creatour, and hath made me after his own Image: I am now glad to Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; as though I were but a Å¿heepe? and yet perhaps no Fall in this at all: For, what was I, when I was at beÅ¿t, but the Lords Å¿heepe? Depending wholly upon him for all I had: No cloathes to cover my nakedneÅ¿Å¿e, but of his making: no food to Å¿atisfie my hunger, but of his providing: and oh that I had continued his Å¿heepe Å¿till, for then though weake, I Å¿hould have beene innocent, though feeble, I Å¿hould have been harmeleÅ¿Å¿e; Where by taking (O miÅ¿erable miÅ¿taking) the Serpent for a Å¿hepheard, I became
of an innocent Sheepe, a ravening Wolfe, and Å¿hould have Å¿o continued, at leaÅ¿t a perpetuall Å¿trayer: if my true Å¿hepheard (O the wonderfull bowells of compaÅ¿Å¿ion) had not left the Ninetie nine in the WilderneÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿eeke after mee, and had not found mee out, and brought me back againe into his Fold; that if there be joy in Heaven, that the loÅ¿t Å¿heepe is found, there ought to bee much more joy in Earth, that the loÅ¿t Å¿heepe can Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; I Å¿hall not want?

But how can I truly Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; Å¿eeing hee hath turned me over, Å¿heepe and lambes and all, to Saint Peter to be our Å¿hepheard? Can he turne me over to another, and yet himÅ¿elfe reteine a propertie in me Å¿till? But is it not that there is a Hierarchie of Å¿hepheards? Saint Peter and his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ours, but MiniÅ¿teriall Å¿hepheards; God himÅ¿elfe the Å¿hepheard Paramount; PÅ¿al. 77.20 Hee ledd his people like Å¿heepe by the hand of MoÅ¿es and Aaron: Hee but uÅ¿ed the Å¿ervice of MoÅ¿es and Aaron; himÅ¿elfe was the Å¿hepheard Å¿till; it was hee that led them. And is it not Å¿aid of Kings too, that they are ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , Shepheards of the people? and perhaps David Å¿peakes here, as hee was a King: for though a King be a Å¿hepheard in relation to his Subjects; yet he is but a Å¿heep in relation to God: for relation in all created things, makes quidlibet ex quolibet; a Å¿heepe of a Å¿hepheard, and a Å¿hepheard of a Å¿heepe, till
we come at God, and there Relation ceaÅ¿eth; for God being Å¿ummum bonum, unum & idem, can take no diÅ¿paragement by any relation, we are all Å¿heepe to him; David and Kings; Saint Peter and all; All faine to Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; or elÅ¿e, can neuer truly Å¿ay; I Å¿hall not want.

It is a great happineÅ¿Å¿e for Å¿heepe to have a good Å¿hepheard, but a greater happineÅ¿Å¿e to have him both good and able; many Å¿hepheards are the one, and not the other; few are both; indeed none are both; None able to Å¿ecure from want, but onely the Å¿hepheard, who is Elohim Saddai; God All-Å¿ufficient. Kings no doubt are able Å¿hepheards, but yet not able to Å¿ecure from want; for we Å¿ee them often-times to be in want themÅ¿elves: Saint Peter an able Å¿hepheard, yet not Å¿o able, as to Å¿ecure from want; for who knowes not what want he was in himÅ¿elfe, when time was? Wee Å¿hall never be Å¿heepe Å¿ecure from want, till wee come to Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; and then wee may juÅ¿tly inferre: We Å¿hall not want.

Indeed God is a Å¿hepheard, as able as hee is good, and as good as he is able. For hee leadeth mee into greene paÅ¿tures. Not onely hee hath greene paÅ¿tures to lead me into, which Å¿hewes his Abilitie; but hee leads mee into them, which Å¿hewes his GoodneÅ¿Å¿e. Hee leades me not into paÅ¿tures that are withered and drye, that would diÅ¿taÅ¿te me before I taÅ¿te them: but
he leades me into Greene paÅ¿tures, as well to pleaÅ¿e my eye with the verdure, as my Å¿tomacke with the herbage; and inviting me as it were to eate, by Å¿etting out the meat in the beÅ¿t colour. A meat though never Å¿o good, yet if it looke not handÅ¿omely, it dulls the appetite: but when beÅ¿ides the goodneÅ¿Å¿e, it hath alÅ¿o a good looke; This gives the appetite another edge, and makes a joy before enjoying. But yet the goodneÅ¿Å¿e is not altogether in the greenneÅ¿Å¿e. Alas, Greene is but a colour, and colours are but deceitfull things, they might be greene leaves; or they might bee greene flags, or ruÅ¿hes: and what good were to mee in Å¿uch a greenneÅ¿Å¿e? No my Å¿oule, the goodneÅ¿Å¿e is in being greene PaÅ¿tures, for now they performe as much as they promiÅ¿e; and as in being greene, they were a comfort to mee as Å¿oone as I Å¿aw them; Å¿o in being greene paÅ¿tures, they are a refreÅ¿hing to me now, as Å¿oone as I taÅ¿t them. As they are pleaÅ¿ant to looke on, Å¿o they are wholÅ¿ome to feed on: As they are Å¿weet to be taÅ¿ted, Å¿o they are eaÅ¿ie to bee digeÅ¿ted; that I am now me thinkes in a kind of ParadiÅ¿e, and Å¿eeme not to want any thing, unleÅ¿Å¿e perhaps a little water, with which now and then to waÅ¿h my mouth, at moÅ¿t to take Å¿ometimes a Å¿ippe: for though Å¿heepe bee no great drinkers; and though their paÅ¿tures being greene, and full of Å¿appe, make drinke the leÅ¿Å¿e needfull, yet Å¿ome drinke they muÅ¿t have
beÅ¿ides; and now Å¿ee the great goodneÅ¿Å¿e of this Shepheard, and what juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e there is to depend upon his Providence: for hee lets not his Å¿heepe want this neither; but hee leades them beÅ¿ides Å¿till waters; Not waters that roare and make a noyÅ¿e, enough to fright a fearefull Å¿heepe: but waters Å¿till and quiet, that though they drinke but little, yet they may drinke that little without feare. And may I not juÅ¿tly Å¿ay now; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard, I Å¿hall not want?

And yet perhaps there will be want for all this; for is it enough, that he leade them into greene paÅ¿tures, and beÅ¿ides Å¿till waters? May he not leade them in, and preÅ¿ently take them out againe, before their bellyes be halfe full; and Å¿o in Å¿tead of making them happy, make them more miÅ¿erable? Å¿et them in a longing with the Å¿ight, and then fruÅ¿trate them of their expectation? No my Å¿oule; The meaÅ¿ure of this Shepheards goodneÅ¿Å¿e, is more then Å¿o; Hee not onely leadeth them into greene paÅ¿tures, but hee makes them to lye downe in them; Hee leades them not in, to poÅ¿t over their meat, as if they were to eate a PaÅ¿Å¿eover, and to take it in TranÅ¿itu, as dogges drinke Nylus; but, hee makes them to lye downe in greene paÅ¿tures, that they may eat their fill, and feed at leiÅ¿ure; and when they have done, lye downe and take their eaÅ¿e, that their After-reckoning may be as pleaÅ¿ing as their RepaÅ¿t;
and that they may be free from being Å¿olliciti de craÅ¿tino, for taking care to provide for tomorrow, Å¿eeing they have a Market of proviÅ¿ion round about them, or rather their meat ready dreÅ¿t to their hands for many dayes to come. O my Å¿oule, thus are the godly provided for, by the Lord their Shepheard; and though their paÅ¿tures may Å¿eeme withered, and dry in the eyes of the world; yet to them, they are greene, and pleaÅ¿ing, and give more gladneÅ¿Å¿e to their hearts; then theirs whoÅ¿e Corne and Wine, moÅ¿t abundantly increaÅ¿eth. And now, O my Å¿oule, is it not time now to Å¿ay Grace, and to acknowledge a thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e for this plenty of my meat, and drinke? and can I Å¿ay a Å¿hortet Grace then this; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; I Å¿hall not want?

And yet perhaps there will be want for all this; for if God be a Shepheard, will hee not Å¿heare his Å¿heepe? and if hee Å¿heare me; will he not leave me bare and naked? and how then can I Å¿ay; I Å¿hall not want? God indeed is a Shepheard, that will Å¿heare his Å¿heepe; but hee will Tondere, not Deglubere; Hee will take off our old cloathes, but it is to make way for new; and he takes them off, in a time, when we may well Å¿pare them; indeed in a time, when it is better for us to be without them: and therefore, neither is his Å¿hearing any cauÅ¿e, but I may Å¿ay Å¿till; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard, I Å¿hall not want.

And yet I Å¿ay Å¿till, there will perhaps bee want for all this: For is it enough to have food, and rayment? Is it enough to have eaÅ¿e and plenty? Alas! all theÅ¿e doe but Å¿erve for the body; there is no proviÅ¿ion here for the Å¿oule: and if the Å¿oule be not provided for; all the reÅ¿t, is but the care of Martha, troubled about many things, and none of them needfull. But he that told Martha of her errour, is it like he will commit the like errour himÅ¿elfe? No my Å¿oule, his principall care is of the Å¿oule; for hee reÅ¿toreth my Å¿oule: but as he made mee VerÅ¿e 3 not a living Å¿oule at firÅ¿t, till hee had made the earth, and the fruits of the earth to Å¿erve for my living; Å¿o he ReÅ¿tores not my Å¿oule now, till he hath firÅ¿t ledde me into Greene paÅ¿tures, to Å¿erve for my Å¿uÅ¿tenance: for to what purpoÅ¿e were it to give a life, and not a living? to give a Being; and not give meanes to maintaine that Being? and was it not perhaps from hence, that ChriÅ¿t tooke his patterne; when he taught us, to Pray for daily bread, before wee Pray for forgiveneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿innes? But though he provide firÅ¿t for the body, which was made firÅ¿t; yet he provides moÅ¿t for the Å¿oule, which was given laÅ¿t: Hee but feedes my body, but he reÅ¿tores my Å¿oule: Hee miniÅ¿ters to my body but accidentall and outward things; but inward and Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall to my Å¿oule. And why is it, that God provides more for the Å¿oule, then for the body; but becauÅ¿e the Å¿oule is of
farre more worth then the body? for God is not as man, to take care of things out of fancie, or upon miÅ¿taking: but hee takes care of things according as hee values them, and values them according as they are worth; Numquid cura Deo de Bobis, Doth God take care of Oxen? Indeed the Soule, in compariÅ¿on of the Body; is of farre more value, then the worth of an Oxe, in compariÅ¿on of a man. O that wee could be Å¿o wiÅ¿e, as to know the true value, and worth of the Å¿oule! and to take care of things according to their values! we Å¿hould then certainly be more carefull of the Å¿oule, leÅ¿Å¿e carefull of the body then we are: and be more Å¿enÅ¿ible of that Å¿aying of ChriÅ¿t; What availes it a man, to gaine the whole world, and to loÅ¿e his Å¿oule? It may bee allowed perhaps to men, to provide firÅ¿t for the body, Å¿o they would provide moÅ¿t for the Å¿oule, as God doth here: but to provide firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t, for the body; and laÅ¿t, and leaÅ¿t for the Å¿oule, as moÅ¿t men doe; that I Å¿ay not, all for the body, and nothing for the Å¿oule, as Å¿ome men doe; This muÅ¿t needs be extremely againÅ¿t all good order: Å¿eeing it is Å¿o directly againÅ¿t Gods order.

But to what is it that God reÅ¿tores my Å¿oule? It muÅ¿t be to Å¿omething that my Å¿oule had before, and hath not now: and Å¿o it is: Hee reÅ¿tores it, to its originall puritie, that was now growne foule, and black with Å¿inne: for alas,
what good were it, to have greene paÅ¿tures, and a black Å¿oule! Hee reÅ¿tores it, to its naturall temper in affections, that was growne diÅ¿tempered with violence of PaÅ¿Å¿ions: for alas what good were it, to have Å¿till waters, and turbulent Å¿pirits! Hee reÅ¿tores it indeed to life, that was growne before, in a manner quite dead, and who could reÅ¿tore my Å¿oule to life, but he onely that is the good Shepheard, and gave his life for his Å¿heepe, which no Å¿hepheard ever did but Hee? Saint Peter layd downe his life, but he gave not his life; for he would perhaps have kept it, if he might: and he layd it not downe neither, as a Å¿hepheard for his Å¿heepe, but as a Å¿heepe rather for his Å¿hepheard: but this Shepheard gave his life for his Å¿heepe: Gave it, quia oportuit indeed, becauÅ¿e it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary he Å¿hould give it; but yet, quia voluit too, becauÅ¿e hee would giue it; for if it had not beene voluntarie, it could not have beene acceptable; and if not acceptable, never certainly have Å¿erved for a RanÅ¿ome; and if not RanÅ¿omming, no ReÅ¿toring.

But is it not Å¿aid, The Shepheard was Å¿mitten, and the Å¿heepe were Å¿cattered? and what was his Å¿myting, but the Giving his life? and had he not done better to have kept his life, then leaving it, to leave his Å¿heepe to Å¿cattering? O my Å¿oule, though they were Å¿cattered for a time, yet it was but to be gathered together againe with the greater joy: for though
he left his life, yet he left not his Å¿heepe: but had a care of them, even in death; for hee had power to lay downe his life, and power to take it up againe: and as he layd it downe for his Å¿heepes RanÅ¿ome, Å¿o hee tooke it up for their juÅ¿tification.

Every Å¿hepheard knowes that Å¿heepe are Å¿ubject to many infirmities, and knowes many infirmities to which they are Å¿ubject; and therefore is never without his Boxe of Tarre, as the beÅ¿t remedie in caÅ¿es of danger; but if the danger paÅ¿Å¿e his Tarre-boxe, and touch upon the life; he then gives them over, and lets nature worke: but the Lord is a Shepheard of another nature, above the power of Nature; He reÅ¿toreth the Å¿oule, when the life is in danger; hee hath wayes of curing, which no Å¿hepheard knows of but himÅ¿elfe; and if other helps fayle, he need but to Å¿ay, Velo, Å¿is Å¿anus; I will, Be thou whole: and without any Tarre-boxe, it is a preÅ¿ent remedie. And may I not now juÅ¿tly Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; I Å¿hall not want?

And yet perhaps there will be want for all this: for is it enough, that he reÅ¿tore my Å¿oule, and then leave me? What is it to reÅ¿tore my Å¿oule, but to put it in Å¿tatu quo prius, in the Å¿tate it was made at firÅ¿t; which, was after the Image of God in holineÅ¿Å¿e, and righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e? and if I could not continue in this Å¿tate, when made in it, how Å¿hall I continue in it, when reÅ¿tored
to it? Hee will therefore Å¿upply this want too: for having reÅ¿tored my Å¿oule in righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e; Hee will leade mee in the paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e: that though left to my Å¿elfe, I tooke a wrong guide, and went aÅ¿tray; yet when he leades me, that is the way it Å¿elfe; I may be Å¿ure, I cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly goe out of the way.

But alas, O Lord, theÅ¿e paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, have a long time Å¿o little beene frequented, that all prints of a path, are almoÅ¿t cleane worne out; that it is a hard matter now but to find where the paths lye, and if wee can find them, yet they are Å¿o narrow, and Å¿o full of rubbes; that without Å¿peciall aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, it is an impoÅ¿Å¿ible thing, not to Fall, or goe aÅ¿tray. Even Å¿ome Angels, and thoÅ¿e no meane ones, were not able to goe right in theÅ¿e pathes of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e; but for want of leading, went awry, and periÅ¿hed. O therefore, Thou the great Shepheard of my Å¿oule, as thou art pleaÅ¿ed of thy grace to leade me into them; Å¿o vouchÅ¿afe with thy Grace to leade me in them: for though in themÅ¿elves they bee pathes of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e; yet to me, they will bee but paths of errour, if thou vouchÅ¿afe not, as well to leade me in them, as into them. O the comfortable pathes of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e; the very paths in which Enoch walked with God, and which walked in as they Å¿hould be, will bring us to a better ParadiÅ¿e, then that of our
firÅ¿t Parents. For if God leade us in theÅ¿e paths; theÅ¿e paths will leade us to the place, where the Goats Å¿hall be put on the left hand, and the Å¿heepe be taken on the right, that now I am certainly come to the higheÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of my glorying to Å¿ay; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard, I Å¿hall not want: for at his right hand is the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of Joy forevermore.

But why is it, that this great Shepheard will doe theÅ¿e great things for me? Is it becauÅ¿e he findes me to be a Å¿ounder Å¿heepe, and to have fewer blemiÅ¿hes upon me then Å¿ome other? Alas no; for I am nothing but blemiÅ¿hes, and unÅ¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e all over; but, Hee will doe it for his Names Å¿ake; For Å¿eeing hee hath taken upon him the Name of a good Å¿hepheard, he will diÅ¿charge his part, what ever his Å¿heepe be: It is not their being bad Å¿heepe, that can make him leave being a good Å¿hepheard, but he will be good, and maintaine the credit of his Name, in Å¿pight of all their badneÅ¿Å¿e: and though no benefit come to them of it, yet there Å¿hall glory accrew to him by it, and his Name Å¿hall nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e be magnified, and extolled.

But now, O my Å¿oule, though I can Å¿ay, I Å¿hall not want: yet can I Å¿ay, I Å¿hall not feare? For is not Feare an inÅ¿eparable companion of Mortalitie? and can I then chooÅ¿e but feare, that know my Å¿elfe to be mortall, and know alÅ¿o what the condition is of being mortall?
Not onely that I may dye, but that I muÅ¿t dye: and not onely muÅ¿t one day, but may this day; Alas, this very minute! I feare indeed when I conÅ¿ider my owne frailtie: but when I conÅ¿ider that the Lord is my Shepheard, I then am armed againÅ¿t all feare, againÅ¿t this feare of death it Å¿elfe: Hee that makes me to walke in Greene paÅ¿tures, and in paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and keepes me from want: hee alÅ¿o leades me by the hand, as I walke, and keepes me from feare: Yea, thou I walke in the VerÅ¿e 4 valley, of the Å¿hadow of death, I will feare no evill: Though I be brought to never Å¿o great extremitie: though brought as low as the Valley of death, though brought as neere to Death, as the Å¿hadow to the body; though brought to walke as a ghoÅ¿t amongÅ¿t the dead, yet I will feare no evill. The Å¿hadow of death may perhaps be farre enough from it, for all our life, is but the Å¿hadow of death: but the Valley of the Å¿hadow muÅ¿t needs be cloÅ¿e to death, as being the very entrance to it; yet if I were brought to this doore of death, if brought within the doore, and compaÅ¿Å¿ed about with Death; yet for all this, for all that can be Å¿aid, or done, I will feare no evill. Will you not? will you not feare evill, when the evill is Å¿o eminent, and the danger Å¿o great? Is the face of Death no more terrible, but that you dare looke upon it, without feare? Though it be the reproach of the wicked, to feare where
there is no cauÅ¿e of feare, yet not to feare where there is cauÅ¿e, can be no commendation in the godly. And why then will David Å¿peake thus, more like a deÅ¿perate man, then one that were well adviÅ¿ed? No doubt, David will give good reaÅ¿on for that hee Å¿peakes; As it were deÅ¿peratneÅ¿Å¿e, not to feare, where there is Imminent danger: So it were cowardiÅ¿e to feare, where there is eminent comfort: Lay then the comfort to the danger, and you will eaÅ¿ily excuÅ¿e David, for fearing no evill. You have Å¿eene the Danger, now heare the Comfort: The Lord my Å¿hepheard is with mee; For he is never abÅ¿ent from his flock: his rodde, and his Å¿taffe, they comfort mee: and may they not juÅ¿tly comfort me, when with them he is able to recover a Å¿heepe, though falling downe the Å¿teepeÅ¿t Praecipyce, or though already in the Wolfes mouth, or in the pawes of the Lyon. Indeed, if I had not my Shepheard with mee; Or if my Shepheard had not his inÅ¿truments with him, I might juÅ¿tly then be in feare of evill; but what evill can I feare now, when I have my Shepheard, and my Shepheard his InÅ¿truments; his rod, and his Å¿taffe; Both InÅ¿truments of comfort; and not onely of comfort, but of incouragement; both InÅ¿truments of preÅ¿erving.

But is it well underÅ¿tood, what his Rod, and his Staffe meane? For, they may as well bee inÅ¿truments of correcting, as defending: and if
of defending, there is then juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e they Å¿hould be comforts: but if of correcting, what comforts can they be? for what comfort can it be, to be corrected? O my Å¿oule, great comfort to me, that know the nature of this Shepheard, as I doe: for doe not I know, that whom he loves, he corrects; and therefore whom he corrects, it is a certaine Argument that hee loves? Indeed, if the Rodde and the Staffe, were in the hands of an enemie; I Å¿hould then feare them, as inÅ¿truments for my evill; but being in his hands that is my Shepheard; now they are but as my owne weapons put into an abler hand, that can better manage them for my good, then I could doe my Å¿elfe. Could MoÅ¿es with his rod fetch water out of a Rock, and Å¿hall not God with his rod, bring comfort out of trouble? Could Jacob with his Å¿taffe paÅ¿Å¿e over Jordan, and returne enriched with heards of cattell, and Å¿hall not Gods Å¿taffe make me paÅ¿Å¿e over the Jordan of this world, and bring mee home with troopes of joy? Shall not his rod, though it wound me, comfort me; when I know he wounds, but to the end hee may apply a PlaiÅ¿ter? Shall not his Å¿taffe, though it beat me, comfort me; when it is but to beat the duÅ¿t out of mee, that am nothing but duÅ¿t? But moÅ¿t of all, muÅ¿t not his rod needs comfort me, when it is his rod, that makes me lye downe in greene paÅ¿tures? MuÅ¿t not his Å¿taffe needs comfort me, when it is his
Å¿taffe, that keepes me right in the paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e? Oh Å¿weet Rod, how can I chooÅ¿e but kiÅ¿Å¿e thee! Deare Å¿taffe, but embrace thee! Å¿eeing it is long of you, that his greene paÅ¿tures, and his paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e doe me any good; for they would certainly doe mee hurt; his greene paÅ¿tures would pamper up my fleÅ¿h too much; his pathes of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e would puffe up my Å¿pirits too much; If his Rod, and his Staffe were not uÅ¿ed as Moderatours. And if you thinke this Å¿trange, that the paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould puffe up the Å¿pirits: Remember Saint Paul, to whom there was given a thorne in the fleÅ¿h, leÅ¿t his walking in the paths of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿hould puffe him up. But if the rod, and the Å¿taffe, in theÅ¿e Å¿enÅ¿es, may not be Å¿ufficient comfort to take away all cauÅ¿e of feare; at leaÅ¿t, there Å¿hall come forth a Rod, out of the Å¿temme of JeÅ¿Å¿e: (indeed to David in particular, a Å¿peciall comfort) that will certainly be Å¿ufficient againÅ¿t all feare, though I walke in the Valley of the Å¿hadow of death; for this Rod, as a Mountaine Å¿hall fill up all Valleys; and as the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, Å¿hall fulfill all Å¿hadowe; and as the true life, Å¿hall Å¿wallow up Death in victory. And is there not a Å¿taffe that will doe as much? the Å¿taffe upon which Jacob leaned, when he was a dying? when he was indeed in the Valley of the Å¿hadow of Death? O my Å¿oule, having this Staffe of Jacob to leane upon; this Rodde of the Å¿temme
of JeÅ¿Å¿e to be my comfort; I Å¿hall make my Å¿elfe unworthy of protection, if I Å¿hould feare any evill, though I walke in the valley of the Å¿hadow of death. For why Å¿hould I feare Death, which is but the parting of the Å¿oule from the body, Å¿eeing I cannot come to God with them both at once, but they muÅ¿t firÅ¿t bee parted one from another? My Å¿oule cannot come to the light of life, if my body bee not firÅ¿t in the Å¿hadow of death: indeed but in the Å¿hadow, for the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of death can never take hold upon it, if my Å¿oule be gone before to take poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Light. O then vouchÅ¿afe, O God, to bring my Å¿oule firÅ¿t, and after it, my body out of the Å¿hadow of Death, into the light of Life; and then I Å¿hall have cauÅ¿e, juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to Å¿ay, and to glory in Å¿aying; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard, I Å¿hall not want.

But if it be doubted Å¿till, how it can be, that Gods rodde, and his Å¿taffe, Å¿hould be comforts to the godly, then marke the iÅ¿Å¿ue, and Å¿ee what followes upon his Rod, and his Staffe; Thou prepareÅ¿t a Table before mee, in the preÅ¿ence VerÅ¿e 5 of my enemies: Thou anoynteÅ¿t my head with Oyle; my cuppe runneth over. For this is a Å¿ure rule with God, that his chaÅ¿tening alwayes ends in cheriÅ¿hing; if he Å¿trike with his Rod, and perhaps breakes the head with his Staffe; he gives Oyle preÅ¿ently to anoynt it, and to make it whole againe. If he make mee to keepe FaÅ¿ting-day to day, he allowes mee a feaÅ¿t for it
to morrow, and then my cuppe Å¿hall runne over.

Hitherto God hath vouchÅ¿afed to bee a Shepheard, and David hath beene his Å¿heepe; Now God will be a Conquerour, and David Å¿hall be a King. Now God as a Conquerour will beÅ¿tow favours on his friends, and diÅ¿graces upon his enemies, and therefore now the Scene alters: where it was before in the field, it is now within doores; and where David before Å¿pake in the third PerÅ¿on, he Å¿peakes now in the Å¿econd; Thou prepareÅ¿t a Table before mee; and this is to feaÅ¿t his friends: In the preÅ¿ence of mine enemies; and this is to confound his enemies. To prepare a Table before him, is it Å¿elfe a favour: but the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the favour is in this, that a Table is prepared before him, in the preÅ¿ence of his Enemies. For as there is no Å¿uch joy of proÅ¿peritie to the godly, as when their enemies Å¿ee the proÅ¿peritie they are in; it being a kind of revenge, that God takes upon their enemies, in their behalfe: Å¿o there is no Å¿uch Tragedie to the wicked, as to be made Å¿pectatours of the proÅ¿peritie of the godly; it being the greateÅ¿t affront, that can be to their expectation, to Å¿ee them advanced, whom they both hated, and deÅ¿piÅ¿ed. Could Haman have had a greater affliction, then to Å¿ee Mordecai advanced, and himÅ¿elfe forced to bee an inÅ¿trument in his advancing? Videbunt quem transfixerunt, They Å¿hall Å¿ee him, whom they pierced,
Å¿hall be one of the miÅ¿eries, and perhaps one of the greateÅ¿t in Hell it Å¿elfe.

And now is David a King, and as a King, hath Honour and Plentie; Thou anoynteÅ¿t my head with oyle, This is his Honour; My cuppe runneth over, This is his Plentie: that where he Å¿aid before; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard; I Å¿hall not want: hee may as juÅ¿tly Å¿ay now; The Lord is my rewarder; I Å¿hall abound.

But is it not that in the PerÅ¿on of David here, there is a Reference to ChriÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe; Å¿eeing it is all verefied in him, that is Å¿poken here? Hee that hungred Å¿o long, till Sathan thought he could have eaten Å¿tones, hath now a Table prepared before him; a Table where the godly Å¿hall Å¿it, and eat with him in his Kingdome. Hee that had enemies inÅ¿ulting over him; hath now all his enemies made his foot-Å¿toole; Sinne and Death, Sathan and his members, lye proÅ¿trate under him: Hee that had his Head pricked with thornes, hath now his Head anoynted with Oyle: with the oyle of gladneÅ¿Å¿e above his fellowes. Hee that thirÅ¿ted, and could get but Vinegar to drinke, hath now Å¿uch plenty, that his cup runneth over: All power is given him, both in Heaven and Earth. At leaÅ¿t in the perÅ¿on of David, there will be relation to all the godly: Now Lazarus that could not get Å¿o much as crummes from Dives his Table, Å¿hall have a Table himÅ¿elfe prepared before him: Now Dives that
fared deliciouÅ¿ly every day, Å¿hall bee glad to Å¿tand waiting at Lazarus Table, for a drop of water: that the godly may well be content to be in penurie a-while, Å¿eeing they Å¿hall have a Table ere long prepared before them: They may well be content to let their Enemies bee maÅ¿ters awhile, Å¿eeing they Å¿hall have them ere long to be wayters upon them: They may well be content to hang downe their heads for awhile, Å¿eeing their heads ere long Å¿hall bee anoynted with Oyle: They may well be content to have hard meaÅ¿ure for a time, Å¿eeing the time will be Å¿hortly, that their Cup Å¿hall runne over. And now, O my Å¿oule, will not all this Å¿erve to comfort thee, in this vale of miÅ¿erie? Art thou Å¿o beÅ¿otted on things preÅ¿ent, as to have no conÅ¿ideration, to make no valuation of things to come, and to come Å¿o Å¿hortly? Å¿o Å¿hortly all, that they are put in the PreÅ¿ent tenÅ¿e, as if they were come already?

But if David cannot over-rule thee as a King, let him at leaÅ¿t perÅ¿wade thee as a Prophet; for now you Å¿hall have him a Prophet, and a Votarie, and this is his Prophecie; Surely, Mercy, and goodneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿hall follow mee, all the dayes of my life: and this is his Vow; I will dwell in the houÅ¿e of the Lord for ever.

But is Davids Prophecie like to bee true? will Mercie, and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e, follow him all the dayes of his life? O my Å¿oule, it was true in David, it Å¿hall be true in all the godly: for
whom God loveth, he loveth to the end; and Mercie, and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿hall follow them all the dayes of their life: Mercy, to commiÅ¿erate; and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e to relieve: Mercie to beare with infirmities, and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿upply wants: Mercie to be an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant in AdverÅ¿itie, and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e to be a GoverneÅ¿Å¿e in ProÅ¿peritie. Alas! O Lord, if thy Mercie Å¿hould not follow me, thy JuÅ¿tice would: if thy GoodneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould not follow mee, thy Vengeance would; and then one that were no Prophet, might eaÅ¿ily foretell the miÅ¿erable eÅ¿tate I Å¿hould be in: as now that Mercie and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e follow me; one that is no Prophet may eaÅ¿ily tell the happy condition I Å¿hall be in. Although this perhaps be not Å¿o much a Prophecie, as a Faith in David, at leaÅ¿t a Prophecie which all the godly may make to themÅ¿elves by Faith, to be aÅ¿Å¿ured of the mercy and goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God; and not to follow them for a time, and then give over, but to follow them all the dayes of their life. But what? no longer then all the dayes of their life, and then leave them? No my Å¿oule, but all the dayes of that life, that Å¿hall never leave them. O the comfortable doctrine of Faith! farre more comfortable then Heathen PhiloÅ¿ophie ever knew; for that went no further, then Ante obitum nemo; as though no man could be happy till his death; where by this it appeares that men may bee happy while they live: for if a
man be then happy, when the mercy and goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God follow him, as certainly a greater happineÅ¿Å¿e there cannot be: then Å¿eeing they Å¿urely follow the godly, all the dayes of their life; Å¿urely a godly man is happy while hee lives. But then the Å¿ureneÅ¿Å¿e is long of the mercy, and not of the man: for it Å¿eemes he would goe farre enough from it, if Mercy did not follow him: but now that hee is followed by Mercy and GoodneÅ¿Å¿e, hee cannot goe Å¿o faÅ¿t from them, but they will overtake him, and make him happy. O mercifull God, Å¿o frame my heart, that I may not flye from thy Mercy, and put it to follow mee; at leaÅ¿t let it Å¿o follow me, that it may overtake me: for then I Å¿hall have the happineÅ¿Å¿e to bee able to keepe my vow, that I will dwell in thy houÅ¿e for ever: but rather I Å¿hall have the favour, as an effect of thy Mercy, that I Å¿hall dwell in thy houÅ¿e for ever. For if this be a Vow, it is a Å¿trange one, where all the benefit is to him that makes the Vow, and none at all to whom it is made, for what is it to God, whither I dwell in his houÅ¿e or no? Å¿uch Vowers God may have enow. O my Å¿oule, to vow to dwell in Gods houÅ¿e, is to vow to be his Å¿ervant; and to bee his Å¿ervant, is to Å¿erve him in holineÅ¿Å¿e, and righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, all the dayes of our life; and though this Å¿ervice be no benefit to God, as indeed no more is any thing I can doe, for my goodneÅ¿Å¿e extendeth not to him: yet the Vow to bee his
Å¿ervant being well performed, will bee more acceptable to him, then if I Å¿hould vow as Jepthe did, to Å¿acrifice his onely Daughter.

But wee need not Å¿tand to juÅ¿tifie Davids Vow: for it Å¿eemes not Å¿o much a Vow of David to God; as a favour of God to David, that when his mercy hath followed him all the dayes of his life, he will take him afterwards to live with himÅ¿elfe; and though his body for a time be caÅ¿t out of doores, yet his Å¿oule Å¿hall preÅ¿ently be received into his houÅ¿e, there to dwell with him and his Angels; not as a Å¿ervant, but as Å¿onne; Å¿eeing none but Å¿onnes abide in the houÅ¿e for ever. Which in the perÅ¿on of David, is no leÅ¿Å¿e the Portion, and may be as well the comfort of all the godly, and is but the expreÅ¿Å¿ing of that in a higher Å¿traine; which was Å¿aid at firÅ¿t in a lower Å¿tyle; The Lord is my Å¿hepheard: I Å¿hall not want.

div.head: THE TVVENTIE SEVENTH PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 THe Lord is my light, and my Å¿alvation, whom Å¿hall I feare? the Lord is the Å¿trength of my life; of whom Å¿hall I be afraid?
2 When the wicked; even mine enemies, and my foes, came upon me, to eate up my fleÅ¿h; they Å¿tumbled, and fell.
3 Though an hoÅ¿t Å¿hould encampe againÅ¿t me; my heart Å¿hall not feare; though warre Å¿hould riÅ¿e againÅ¿t me, in this will I be confident.

4 One thing have I deÅ¿ired of the Lord; that will I Å¿eeke after, that I may dwell in the houÅ¿e
of the Lord, all the dayes of my life; to behold the beautie of the Lord; and to inquire in his holy Temple.
5 For in the time of trouble, hee Å¿hall hide mee in his Pavillion; in the Å¿ecret of his Tabernacle Å¿hall hee hide me; he Å¿hall Å¿et me upon a Rock.
6 And now Å¿hall my head be lifted up above mine enemies round about me; therefore will I offer in his Tabernacle Å¿acrifices of joy: I wil Å¿ing; yea, I will Å¿ing praiÅ¿es unto the Lord.
7 Heare, O Lord, when I cry with my voyce: have mercy alÅ¿o upon me, and anÅ¿wer me.
8 When thou Å¿aydÅ¿t; Å¿eeke yee my face; my heart Å¿aid unto thee; thy face Lord, wil I Å¿eeke.
9 Hyde not thy face farre from mee; put not thy Å¿ervant away in anger: Thou haÅ¿t beene my helpe; leave me not, neither forÅ¿ake mee, O God of my Å¿alvation.
10 When my father, and my mother forÅ¿ake mee; then the Lord wil take mee up.
11 Teach me thy way, O Lord, and leade mee in a plaine path, becauÅ¿e of mine enemies.
12 Deliuer mee not over to the wil of mine enemies; for falÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es are riÅ¿en up againÅ¿t mee; and Å¿uch as breathe out crueltie.
13 I had fainted, unleÅ¿Å¿e I had beleeved to Å¿ee the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of the Lord, in the land of the living.
14 Waite on the Lord; bee of good courage, and hee Å¿hall Å¿trengthen thine heart; waite I Å¿ay, on the Lord.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE XXVII. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
LIght which makes all things viÅ¿ible, VerÅ¿e 1 was the firÅ¿t made, of all viÅ¿ible things: and whether God did it, for our example or no, I know not: but ever Å¿ince, in immitation of this manner of Gods proceeding; the firÅ¿t thing we doe, when wee intend to doe any thing, is to get us Light. Indeed Light, is not onely a directour, but a comforter: and nothing naturally Å¿trikes Å¿o much terrour, as DarkneÅ¿Å¿e: for when wee are in the darke, not onely wee are apt to take into our fancies, all frightfull objects, but we know not how to take our Å¿teps, for feare of walls, and threÅ¿holds. It is every ones caÅ¿e, to have the Sunne for his light; but it is not every ones happineÅ¿Å¿e, to have God for his Light; and
alas, if I Å¿hould truÅ¿t to the Sunne for light, I Å¿hould be left in darkneÅ¿Å¿e, every day, at leaÅ¿t at night: but God is a Sunne that never Å¿ets: hee is Light himÅ¿elfe, hee is Light it Å¿elfe: and therefore it is good truÅ¿ting to God for Light: for Å¿o I Å¿hall be Å¿ure, neither day nor night, to be left in darkneÅ¿Å¿e. O thou great Creatour of Light; Thou Light of all creatures, vouchÅ¿afe to Å¿hine upon me, and to lighten my darkneÅ¿Å¿e, that neither any Objects of terrour may make mee to tremble; nor any ThreÅ¿holds of errour may make mee to Å¿tumble, but that I may walke Å¿ecurely in the confidence of this; The Lord is my Light: for of what then, of whom now, Å¿hould I be afraid?

But, is it enough that God bee my Light? what if I my Å¿elfe be blind? what good then will his Light doe mee? It is true; and therefore David Å¿tayes not here; but, Deus illuminatio mea; God is my Enlightening too. Hee is both my Light, and my Å¿ight: my Light, by which to Å¿ee; and my Å¿ight, with which to Å¿ee my Light, to make walls, and threÅ¿holds viÅ¿ible; and my Å¿ight, to make me able to avoide them. If it were not for Light, I Å¿hould be alwayes in the darke; if it were not for Å¿ight, I Å¿hould bee darke my Å¿elfe: No illumination without both: and never both, but onely from God. There is one indeed, who hath gotten him a Name, to be called Lucifer; as though it were hee, that brought us Light: when God
knowes but for him, we Å¿hould have had no darkneÅ¿Å¿e: yet he pretends to both; both to Light, and to enlightning: but alas, his light is but impoÅ¿ture; his enlightning, but illuÅ¿ion: for as he can transforme himÅ¿elfe into an Angell of light; Å¿o he can transforme the light it Å¿elfe, and make it Å¿eeme light, when it is indeed darke: and therefore his light can never make Walls and ThreÅ¿holds to be truly viÅ¿ible: and as little can his enlightening, make us able to avoide them. For this was tryed in our firÅ¿t Parents, who upon his Enlightening, had their eyes opened indeed, but opened to Å¿ee Good and Evill; not to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h good from evill, and therefore could not enable them, cannot us, to avoid the evill. But as they, that follow his light, doe Å¿tumble and fall at the ThreÅ¿hold of errour; Å¿o they that are led by his enlightening, doe run their heads againÅ¿t the Walls of impietie; No avoiding of Walls and ThreÅ¿holds; No Å¿hunning the Å¿nares of Sathan, the illuÅ¿ions of this Lucifer, but onely by Å¿aying, if truly Å¿aying; Deus illuminatio mea, God is my enlightening; and then we may Å¿afely inferre, of what; of whom Å¿hould I be afraid?

Indeed David might well Å¿ay; Deus illuminatio mea; God is my Enlightening: Seeing God had enlightened him, not onely to Å¿ee, but to be a Seer, which is a Prophet: but what is this to us, who are farre from any Å¿uch enlightening, to Å¿ee as Prophets? O my Å¿oule, it is enough
for us; that ChriÅ¿t is the great Seer, in whoÅ¿e Light, wee Å¿hall Å¿ee light: and though David were of the Jewes, and wee bee of the Gentiles; yet as ChriÅ¿t was the glory of his people IÅ¿rael: Å¿o he is a Light, to lighten the Gentiles: and therefore Deus illuminatio mea, God is my enlightening; as fit for us to Å¿ay, as it was for David.

But doth Gods enlightening Å¿erve onely for a Å¿afeguard againÅ¿t Walls and ThreÅ¿holds? Alas! the light of the Sunne, and the enlightening of Nature would Å¿erve to doe this: and what need we then to Å¿eeke any other? O my Å¿oule, there are Å¿pirituall Walls, and ThreÅ¿holds, which no Sunne can make us Å¿ee, which Nature her Å¿elfe is not able to Å¿ee; onely Gods enlightening, hath the influence to doe it. There is a Wall of Å¿inne, the Partition Wall betweene God and us: the Wall that barres us from having acceÅ¿Å¿e to God: and this Wall, the naturall man Å¿ees not, neither can Å¿ee: Illumination onely makes it viÅ¿ible. There is a ThreÅ¿hold of pride in the heart of man; a Å¿welling of Å¿elfe-love, that lyes in the way wee are to paÅ¿Å¿e, and is a cauÅ¿e of Å¿tumbling if not avoyded: and this ThreÅ¿hold the naturall man Å¿ees not, neither can Å¿ee; onely Gods illumination makes able to Å¿ee it. And many other Walls and ThreÅ¿holds there are, which without Illumination can never be Å¿eene; and not Å¿eene, can never be avoided; and not avoided,
are cauÅ¿e of falling into endleÅ¿Å¿e perdition. And as Illumination makes us to Å¿ee theÅ¿e lights of Terrour, Å¿o it makes us to Å¿ee alÅ¿o Å¿ights of Comfort; It makes us Å¿ee Death lye dead before us, and Å¿wallowed up in Victory; It makes us Å¿ee the powers of Hell aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed, as not able to endure the luÅ¿tre of this Light: It makes us Å¿ee the doores of Heaven open, into which by vertue of this Light wee have meanes to enter: It makes us Å¿ee him that is inviÅ¿ible, God himÅ¿elfe that is our enlightening, in whoÅ¿e PreÅ¿ence, is the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of Joy for evermore; and of whom then, of what now Å¿hould I be afraid?

TheÅ¿e indeed bee comfortable Å¿ights, but what comfort for me to Å¿ee them, if I bee not Å¿ure I Å¿hall enjoy them? and how can I be any more Å¿ure to enjoy them, then the Angells that fell? For they had Illumination, in a greater meaÅ¿ure then I can hope to have it; and yet for all their Illumination, they Å¿tumbled at the ThreÅ¿hold of Pride: and ranne their heads againÅ¿t the Wall of Å¿inne, and utterly loÅ¿t; Alas have loÅ¿t for ever, all benefit, of all theÅ¿e comfortable Å¿ights. All this is true, and therefore David Å¿tayes not here neither; but Deus illuminatio mea, & Å¿alus mea; God is my enlightening, and my Å¿alvation too, and this hee was not to the Angels that fell: hee left them at Illumination, never conducted them to Å¿alvation; for if hee had done this, their Illumination had
never beene turned into darkneÅ¿Å¿e; either they had not Å¿tumbled at all. or at leaÅ¿t not Å¿o Å¿tumbled, as to fall. If God were onely my illumination, I Å¿hould by that light goe to Video meliora probo
que , but Å¿hould preÅ¿ently follow it with Deteriora Å¿equor: but when he is my Å¿alvation too; this makes me breake off at Deteriora Å¿equor: and where God was heard to Å¿ay; Perditio tua ex te O IÅ¿rael, Thy deÅ¿truction is from thy Å¿elfe, O IÅ¿rael: Now to heare him Å¿ay, Ego autem Å¿alus tua, but I am thy Å¿alvation. HaÅ¿t thou not promiÅ¿ed to conÅ¿ider man, that he is but duÅ¿t; and Å¿hall anger make thee to forget that PromiÅ¿e?
