Thou haÅ¿t beene my helper heretofore, and why didÅ¿t thou helpe me, but becauÅ¿e I needed thy aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance? and may I not with thy aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance now returne from my evill way; if thou be pleaÅ¿ed not to be Å¿o haÅ¿tie to turne me away? By thy helping me then, thou didÅ¿t expreÅ¿Å¿e thy loving me then; and why then Å¿hould I feare, thou wilt now forÅ¿ake mee? for whom thou loveÅ¿t, thou loveÅ¿t to the end; Not to the end, and then ends; but to the end, that Å¿hall never end. Shall the Heathen have cauÅ¿e, have colour of cauÅ¿e, to upbraid thee with inconÅ¿tancie; that whom thou helpeÅ¿t at one time, thou forÅ¿akeÅ¿t at another? Or canÅ¿t thou turne mee away in anger; and then helpe mee in mercy, when thou haÅ¿t done? CanÅ¿t thou Å¿o Å¿oone change from Mercy to Anger; and from Anger againe to Mercie; that we Å¿hould never know in what temper to find thee? No my Å¿oule, farre be it from thee to have Å¿uch thoughts: but the truth is, Gods wayes are not diÅ¿cerned, not diÅ¿cernable by us, they are paÅ¿t our finding out: We know nothing at any time, what it is he doth; leÅ¿Å¿e, why; and leaÅ¿t of all, how hee
doth it: Both the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and the circumÅ¿tance of all his actions, is to us an AbyÅ¿Å¿us; we know nothing of all his wayes but this, that all his wayes are Mercy, and Truth; nothing of his condition, but this, that in him, there is no change, nor Å¿hadow of change.

VerÅ¿e 10 It is indeed the nature of all living creatures, though never Å¿o tender of their young ones; yet when they are growne to a ripeneÅ¿Å¿e of age and Å¿trength, to turne them off, to Å¿hift for themÅ¿elves; and even a Father and a Mother, as tender as they are, have yet Å¿omewhat of this common nature in them, for while their children are young, they leade them by the hand; but when they are growne up, they leave them to their owne legges; and if they chance to fall, let them riÅ¿e as they can: but God, even then takes his children up, for hee knowes of what they are made; hee knowes their Å¿trength muÅ¿t as well be Å¿upported, as their weakneÅ¿Å¿e be aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted; hee knowes they muÅ¿t as well be taken up, when they fall, as be held up when they Å¿tand; and therefore though the tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of a Father be great, of a Mother perhaps greater; yet no compariÅ¿on to be made with the tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of God. And Å¿eeing God is never without tenderneÅ¿Å¿e, why Å¿hould I be ever without hope? and not hope as well to be delivered from trouble; as others to be preÅ¿erved in Å¿afety? O my Å¿oule, much rather: for Å¿eeing all things in this world are
Å¿ubject to change, is not that hope more like to Å¿ucceed, which hopes for a change, then that which hopes for a continuance?

But Å¿eeing the way of thy tenderneÅ¿Å¿e, is VerÅ¿e 11 paÅ¿t our finding out; O therefore, Doe thou, O God, teach mee thy way, and leade mee in a plaine path, becauÅ¿e of mine enemies. Teach mee thy way, how it can Å¿tand with tenderneÅ¿Å¿e to thy children, to Å¿uffer them to be afflicted, when thou Å¿uffereÅ¿t the wicked to live in proÅ¿peritie? To make Martyrs of thy Å¿ervants, when the wicked flouriÅ¿h, and live at eaÅ¿e? How it can Å¿tand with thy tenderneÅ¿Å¿e, to take away thy Å¿ervants, in the midÅ¿t of their dayes; often-times in the beginning, when thou Å¿uffereÅ¿t the wicked of the world, to runne out the full races of long lives? Why thou leadeÅ¿t the godly in paths of temptations, when thou leadeÅ¿t the wicked in paths of Å¿ecuritie? But if theÅ¿e wayes of thine, be too hard for me to learne; or if thy pleaÅ¿ure bee not to reveale them as yet; at leaÅ¿t, O God, Leade me in a plaine path, becauÅ¿e of mine enemies: If it were not for mine enemies, I would never make this Å¿uite unto thee; but would leave it to thee, to leade me in what paths thou pleaÅ¿eÅ¿t: but having the eyes of Å¿o many enemies upon me; if thou Å¿houldÅ¿t leade me now, in a rugged path, where I might chance to Å¿tumble, or fall; would not my enemies triumph at it, as at a victory? for they marke ever Å¿tep I take, to watch what advantage
they can find againÅ¿t me; and if they Å¿hould find me tripping never Å¿o little, I were Å¿ure to be made the Anvile of their malice, to be beaten upon, without either pitty or compaÅ¿Å¿ion. But how great Å¿oever their malice be; I know they can doe nothing without leave; Thou onely, O God, haÅ¿t an abÅ¿olute power over me; My enemies, none, but by thy permiÅ¿Å¿ion: and I hope, thou wilt retaine thy power in thine owne hands; at leaÅ¿t, not make my enemies, thy deligates. To thy will I willingly VerÅ¿e 12 Å¿ubmit my Å¿elfe: but Deliver mee not over, to the will of my enemies: for thy will, when moÅ¿t Å¿evere, is yet with compaÅ¿Å¿ion; but their will, when moÅ¿t gentle, is alwayes with cruelty: And I Å¿peake not this upon a bare Å¿uÅ¿pition; but I have evident proofes for what I Å¿ay; For, falfe witneÅ¿Å¿es are riÅ¿en up againÅ¿t mee; and Å¿uch as breath out crueltie. I deÅ¿ired indeed to bee led in a plaine path; to the end I might walke upright, both before God and men; that Å¿o I might give my enemies no cauÅ¿e of offence; doe nothing whereof I might bee juÅ¿tly accuÅ¿ed: but alas, what good hath my integritie done me? for Å¿o great is my enemies malice againÅ¿t me; that when they cannot charge mee truly, they accuÅ¿e me falÅ¿ely: and becauÅ¿e they would not be Å¿eene in it themÅ¿elves, they Å¿uborne witneÅ¿Å¿es: and becauÅ¿e one witneÅ¿Å¿e would not be Å¿ufficient, Many; and leÅ¿t their witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hould be apt to relent; they have
gotten Å¿uch, as breath out crueltie; Å¿uch as make crueltie their living, and trade I may Å¿ay, in no wares but cruell. Though I have a thouÅ¿and witneÅ¿Å¿es of my innocencie; my owne conÅ¿cience; yet theÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es will not bee heard in the Courts of the world: Alas no, I know one, an innocent indeed, who had greater witneÅ¿Å¿es then theÅ¿e, the witneÅ¿Å¿es of his pious and wonderfull, and wonderfull pious workes; yet neither would theÅ¿e be taken for witneÅ¿Å¿es of his innocencie; but in the Courts of the world, hee was condemned as guiltie.

O my Å¿oule, I had utterly fainted under this burden, if it had not beene for one thing; If I VerÅ¿e 13 had not beleeved to Å¿ee the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of the Lord, in the land of the living. The onely hope of this, hath kept me from fainting: and how could it chooÅ¿e? being a Cordiall made up of three Å¿overaigne Ingredients; a hope to Å¿ee; and to Å¿ee the goodneÅ¿s of God; and the goodneÅ¿s of God in the land of the living: three Å¿uch Ingredients, that he muÅ¿t be one of a very faint heart, whom Å¿uch a Cordiall will not keepe from fainting.

But what ingredient of comfort, is a hope to Å¿ee? for doe I not Å¿ee now, as well as I am like to doe hereafter? were not our firÅ¿t Parents eyes opened in ParadiÅ¿e; and can wee hope to Å¿ee better, then they Å¿aw there? and doe not our eyes Å¿tand as open as theirs Å¿till? O my Å¿oule, the opening of their eyes then,
hath made us Å¿ee the worÅ¿e ever Å¿ince: wee Å¿ee now, but as in a GlaÅ¿Å¿e, rather appearances of things, then things themÅ¿elves; we Å¿ee nothing now but colours, and colours are deceitfull, and no truÅ¿ting to them: the light I hope for, is to Å¿ee, as I am Å¿eene; a Å¿ight not Å¿ubject to either dimneÅ¿Å¿e, or dazeling: a Å¿ight that diÅ¿cerneth not onely colours, but Å¿ubÅ¿tances; and is not the hope of Å¿uch a Å¿ight, a comfortable Ingredient to keepe from fainting?

But yet what good is it, to Å¿ee goodneÅ¿Å¿e? for we Å¿ee many good things, which yet wee are never the better for Å¿eeing: But is it not true here, Videte & guÅ¿tate? for Å¿uch our Å¿eeing Å¿hall be: Vidchimus & guÅ¿tavimus; our Å¿eeing Å¿hall be a taÅ¿ting; our taÅ¿ting, an enjoying; and enjoying is not properly of any thing, but in which there is joy; and where there is joy, muÅ¿t there not needs be comfort?

But yet what more goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God can wee hope to Å¿ee hereafter, then now? for can there bee a greater goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God to bee Å¿eene then this, that hee makes the Sunne to Å¿hine, the raine to fall, upon both juÅ¿t and unjuÅ¿t? Wee Å¿ee indeed now a great goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God: but wee Å¿ee it mingled with much badneÅ¿Å¿e of men; and may I not Å¿ay with Å¿ome badneÅ¿Å¿e of his too? for is there any evill in the Citie, and God hath not done it? but the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God which I hope to Å¿ee, is a goodneÅ¿Å¿e like to garbled Å¿pice,
without any mixture at all of refuÅ¿e Å¿tuffe amongÅ¿t it: a goodneÅ¿Å¿e not mingled with either evill of men, or evill to men; but pure and Impermixt as God himÅ¿elfe is. The goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God which we Å¿ee now, is a goodneÅ¿Å¿e in effects; but there is a goodneÅ¿Å¿e in God, which is as the cauÅ¿e: Not as having goodneÅ¿Å¿e, but as being goodneÅ¿Å¿e: Not onely as imparting it Å¿elfe to us, but as communicating it Å¿elfe with us; and this goodneÅ¿Å¿e wee Å¿hall then Å¿ee, though now we cannot. Have PhiloÅ¿ophers conceived, that if vertue could be Å¿eene with the eyes, Mirabiles excitaret amores Å¿ui; It would Å¿tirre up in us a wonderfull love; and will not the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God, when Å¿eene with our eyes, Å¿tirre up in our hearts, a wonderfull joy? and is not the hope of Å¿uch a joy a Å¿trong Cordiall to keepe from fainting?

But why in the land of the living? for is not the world in which wee now live, the land of the living? Are there not, in the water, living fiÅ¿hes? in the Ayre, living Birds? On the Earth, living Trees, living BeaÅ¿ts, living Men? and what can be thought of, more then theÅ¿e, to make a Land of the living? Alas! what Land of the living is this, in which there are more dead then living; more under ground, then are above it: where the earth is fuller of graves then houÅ¿es; where life lyes trembling under the hand of Death, and where Death hath power to tyrannize over
life? No my Å¿oule, there onely is the Land of the living, where there are none but the living; where there is a Church not Militant, but Triumphant, a Church indeed, but no Churchyard, becauÅ¿e none dead, nor none that can dye: where life is not paÅ¿Å¿ive; nor Death active: where Life Å¿its crowned; and where Death is Å¿wallowed up in victorie. And now make up a Compound of theÅ¿e Ingredients: Take firÅ¿t, a Hope of Å¿eeing, which is enjoying: then the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God, not a qualitie, but a Å¿ubÅ¿tance: then the Land of the living, where there is no dying: and now Å¿ay, if Å¿uch a Cordial muÅ¿t not needs be Å¿trong, of neceÅ¿Å¿itie be effectuall, to keepe from fainting? O therefore my Å¿oule, bee Å¿ure to provide thee good Å¿tore of this Cordiall, that if at any time thou be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, with either multitude, or malice; if at any time falÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es bee riÅ¿en up againÅ¿t thee; if enemies at any time come upon thee, to eat up thy fleÅ¿h; thou maiÅ¿t have this Cordiall in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, and be able to Å¿ay; Doe the worÅ¿t you can, I feare you not; for I beleeve to Å¿ee the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God in the Land of the living. This not onely will keepe thee from fainting, but wil fill thy Å¿pirits, with extaÅ¿ie of joy: for it is grounded upon a principle of comfort, delivered by Saint Paul; The afflictions of this life, are not worthy of the glory that Å¿hall be revealed: And what is this glory, but to Å¿ee the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God? and where
to be revealed, but in the Land of the living?

But all this yet, is but the hope of a Cordiall; at moÅ¿t, but a Cordiall of hope: but when will the Cordiall it Å¿elfe, that is hoped for, bee had? May I not Å¿tay Å¿o long waiting for it, that I may be weary with waiting, and faint with wearineÅ¿Å¿e? and then the Cordiall will come too late? No my Å¿oule, Waite on the VerÅ¿e 14 Lord; be of good courage, and he Å¿hall give thee Å¿trength: for as none is Å¿o worthy to be waited on, as God; Å¿o nothing is Å¿o worthy to be waited for, as this Cordiall: and never feare wearineÅ¿Å¿e by long waiting for it, Å¿o long as thou waiteÅ¿t upon God for it: for, God that gives power to the Cordiall, to keepe thee from fainting, will give power to thy waiting, to keepe it from wearineÅ¿Å¿e. Onely bee Å¿ure to have a good heart, and God will not faile to Å¿upply it with Å¿pirits: Doe thou but onely bring wood to the Sacrifice, and God will Å¿end fire from Heaven to kindle it.

But how happens it, that David Å¿hould give Å¿o good counÅ¿ell to others, and yet follow it Å¿o ill himÅ¿elfe? for hee confeÅ¿Å¿eth of himÅ¿elfe in another place; that hee is dejected, and bowed downe; and can it Å¿tand with courage, to be dejected? But is it not, that to be dejected, is a PaÅ¿Å¿ive infirmitie, to be couragious, an Active vertue; and there is no contradiction, to bee PaÅ¿Å¿ively weake, and Actively Å¿trong, both at once. Or is it not indeed rather, that when he
confeÅ¿Å¿eth himÅ¿ele to be dejected, hee lookes upon his Å¿inne; and Å¿inne will deject any, that hath but eyes, and is able to Å¿ee it; but when he counÅ¿ells to be couragious, hee lookes upon God; and God is ready to give Å¿trength to any, that hath but a heart, and is able to take it. As therefore I Å¿aid before, Å¿o I Å¿ay againe; Waite on the Lord: which can never be too much taught, becauÅ¿e never enough be learned; never be too much Å¿aid, becauÅ¿e never be enough done.

div.head: THE THIRTIETH PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 I Will extoll thee, O Lord; for thou haÅ¿t lifted me up, and haÅ¿t not made my foes to rejoyce over me.
2 O Lord, my God, I cryed unto thee; and thou haÅ¿t healed mee.
3 O Lord, thou haÅ¿t brought up my Å¿oule from the grave; thou hast kept mee alive, that I Å¿hould not goe downe to the pit.
4 Sing unto the Lord, all yee Saints of his; and give thankes at the remembrance of his holineÅ¿Å¿e.

5 For his anger endureth but a moment; weeping
may endure for a night; but joy commeth in the morning.
6 And in my proÅ¿perity I Å¿aid, I Å¿hall never be moved.
7 Lord by thy favour thou haÅ¿t made my mountaine to Å¿tand Å¿trong; Thou didÅ¿t hide thy face, and I was troubled.
8 I cryed unto thee, O Lord; and unto the Lord, I made Å¿upplication.
9 What profit is there in my bloud, when I goe downe into the pit? Å¿hall the duÅ¿t praiÅ¿e thee? Å¿hall it declare thy truth?
10 Heare, O Lord; have mercy upon mee; Lord be thou my helper.
11 Thou haÅ¿t turned for mee, my mourning into dauncing: Thou haÅ¿t put off my Å¿ack-cloath, and girded mee with gladneÅ¿Å¿e.
12 To the end that my glory may Å¿ing praiÅ¿e to thee, and not be Å¿ilent; O Lord, my God, I will give thankes unto thee for ever.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE XXX. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
IT Å¿eemes to be a courÅ¿e in Nature, VerÅ¿e 1 for HoÅ¿anna's alwayes to precede Allelujahs; and therefore the Exordiums of Davids PÅ¿almes are commonly thus; Have mercy upon mee, O God: heare my prayer, O Lord, rebuke mee not in thine anger: or Å¿ome Å¿uch forme of HoÅ¿anna: but in this PÅ¿alme, contrary to his cuÅ¿tome, he makes his Exordium of an Allelujah: I will extoll thee, O God: And why is this done? is it out of Devotion, that he might get before hand, and begin with God in PraiÅ¿es, before God Å¿hould begin with him in Benefits? O my Å¿oule, the Å¿howres of Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ings are Å¿o continually poured downe upon us, that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible we Å¿hould ever get before hand with God in Allelujahs. Although
therefore he begin with an Allelujah, yet it is becauÅ¿e God hath prevented him in his HoÅ¿anna: Hee will extoll God, but it is becauÅ¿e God hath lifted him up: Gods praiÅ¿e indeed is put in the PreÅ¿ent TenÅ¿e, but it is becauÅ¿e his benefit is in the Preterperfect TenÅ¿e: I will extoll thee, O God; for thou haÅ¿t lifted mee up, and haÅ¿t not made my foes to rejoyce over me.

But if David will extoll God; how will he doe it? for to doe it unworthily, it were better to be left undone, and who is able to extoll God worthily? Hee will therefore perhaps call all the creatures of God to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him, and Å¿ay; PraiÅ¿e the Lord, all yee his Angels; PraiÅ¿e him all his HoÅ¿ts; praiÅ¿e yee him Sun and Moone; praiÅ¿e him all yee Å¿tarres of light: Let every thing that hath breath, praiÅ¿e the Lord. But if it be expected he muÅ¿t extoll him himÅ¿elfe; and not looke for helpe from others; Hee will then extoll him in his exaltation, and Å¿ay; Bee thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: Or, he will extoll him in his owne humilitie, by kneeling, and falling downe before him: hee will extoll him in his Å¿ingularitie, and Å¿ay; There is no other God in heaven, or in earth, but onely, thou O God: or he will extoll him in his pluralitie, and Å¿ay; Thou, O God, art wonderfull in thy Being; Three PerÅ¿ons, and one God, bleÅ¿Å¿ed for ever. And if to extoll him with Å¿ayings will not Å¿erve, he will then extoll him with workes, that men Å¿eeing his good workes, may glorifie
our Father which is in heaven. And if neither words nor workes will be Å¿ufficient; hoe will then extoll him with his Å¿ilence, and his wonder: leaving that for Thought which cannot be expreÅ¿t: and leaving that for aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment which cannot be conceived.

But why is it that David will thus extoll God? Is it, that hee may returne a thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e anÅ¿werable to the benefit: returne it in the Å¿ame kind, and anÅ¿wer it, as it were in its owne language? He will therefore extoll God, which is a kind of lifting God up: becauÅ¿e God hath lifted him up, which is a kind of extolling of him. For as our extolling of God, is the higheÅ¿t worke of our thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o Gods lifting us up, is the greateÅ¿t benefit of his goodneÅ¿Å¿e. We are thankfull to God, and ought to be, for his other benefits, even for caÅ¿ting us downe: but we uÅ¿e not to extoll him, but for lifting us up: For naturally indeed, wee are all of us deÅ¿irous to bee lifted up; to be Å¿et aloft, and to be high in the world: for this pleaÅ¿eth the eyes, that they may Å¿ee the more, and pleaÅ¿eth the whole body, that it may the more bee Å¿eene: but this is not the lifting up that David meanes; but to be lifted up out of danger; and out of the reach of the arme of his enemies. O my Å¿oule, let this bee thy comfort, that although thy enemies be many, and great, yet they are not more thy enemies, then they are Gods Å¿laves; and can goe no further, then the
length of their chaine, which is Å¿eldome Å¿o long to reach to triumphing. Sathan was a bitter enemie to Job, and had certainly defeated him utterly, if God had not held him Å¿hort in his chaine; and though linke after linke, hee eetched out his chaine to a great length, yet he could never make it reach Å¿o farre, as to a Triumph. For it is not properly a Triumph, but when Dux Duci arma detrahit; When one Generall diÅ¿armes another: and this could never be done to Job; for he kept on his Armour Å¿till; his Helmet of Faith; and his BreÅ¿t-plate of RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, hee never let it goe off from him: that there could be no cauÅ¿e for Sathan to triumph. Men commonly are not Å¿atiÅ¿fied, unleÅ¿Å¿e themÅ¿elves can triumph over their enemies: but it is enough for me, O Lord, that thou Å¿uffer not my enemies to triumph over me: for I aime not at glory, but at Å¿afetie; I might then ayme at glory, if I were the aÅ¿Å¿ailant: but now that I am onely the aÅ¿Å¿ailed; what can I more deÅ¿ire then Å¿afetie, and to bee out of the reach of all my enemies? and Å¿uch Å¿afetie, without any glory, may well give contentment, Å¿eeing of all the miÅ¿eries that can befall a man in this wretched world; there is none greater, none Å¿o great, as to fall into the hands of enemies, whoÅ¿e Malice, like the fire of Hell, is commonly unquenchable. Let a friend Å¿trike me, and it Å¿hall be a Balme to my head; but to be Å¿trucken by an enemie, who can endure
it? The Å¿triking of a friend is out of love, and intends amendment; but the blowes of an enemie are out of malice, and tend to ruine. It troubles mee not, that my enemies rejoyce, Å¿o their rejoycing have no relation to mee: It troubled not SamÅ¿on Å¿o much, to have his eyes put out, as to bee brought out before his enemies, to be the laughing-Å¿tock for them to rejoyce at.

But why will David Å¿peake thus; Thou haÅ¿t not made my enemies to rejoyce over me: as though it were God, that made our enemies to rejoyce over us, and not their owne Å¿pitefulneÅ¿Å¿e and malice? Is it, that permiÅ¿Å¿ion is in God a kind of action; and therefore he may juÅ¿tly be Å¿aid to doe that, which he Å¿uffers to be done? Or is it, that in his anger, he makes our enemies the Executioners of his juÅ¿tice: and puniÅ¿heth our neglect of rejoycing in him, with giving them power to rejoyce over us? and Å¿o their rejoycing, is not more in us, his judgement; then it is in them his act and operation.

But what enemies do we talk of, all this while? worldly minds have no feare, but of worldly enemies; and from Å¿uch, perhaps worldly friends may free them: but the Å¿pirituall man feares rather Å¿piritual enemies; and who can free them from Å¿uch, but onely thou, O God, that art the God of Å¿pirits? O mercifull God, let not Å¿pirituall enemies have the victory over mee; and I make no great reckoning of other enemies
triumphing: Alas! I know that worldly enemies can never triumph over me, if Å¿pirituall enemies get not firÅ¿t the victory.

And now, O my Å¿oule, if God have done this for me, have lifted me up above theÅ¿e enemies, above theÅ¿e enemies of both kindes, have I not a double cauÅ¿e to extoll him for it, and to praiÅ¿e his Name? And yet I may Å¿ay, I extoll him not more for doing it, then for his readineÅ¿Å¿e of doing it; For I cryed unto him, and hee healed mee: I no Å¿ooner cryed, but hee heard me; he no Å¿ooner heard me, but he healed me; My Å¿uite was no Å¿ooner made, then granted; My diÅ¿eaÅ¿e as Å¿oone cured, as diÅ¿covered; hee kept me not languiÅ¿hing, by drawing out his cure in length; but he applyed a preÅ¿ent remedy, and prevented Hope with haÅ¿t. As therefore I extolled him before for his love, in lifting me up above my enemies; Å¿o I muÅ¿t extoll him now for his compaÅ¿Å¿ion, in being moved to doe it, for my onely crying to him; I uÅ¿ed no interceÅ¿Å¿our, but my owne voyce, and hee healed me; and for God to be moved with the cry of a wretched Å¿inner; and Å¿o to be moved, as preÅ¿ently to heale him; Is it not a juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to extoll him, and Å¿ay; O the wonderfull bowels of compaÅ¿Å¿ion that are in God?

VerÅ¿e 3 To be lifted up from any place, is an act of Power; but the lower the place is, it is the greater act of Mercie; and can there be a lower place then the Grave? at leaÅ¿t, then the grave
of the Soule? and from this low place, was David lifted up, as yee may heare himÅ¿elfe Å¿ay; Thou, O Lord haÅ¿t brought up my Å¿oule from the grave; Thou haÅ¿t kept mee alive, that I Å¿hould not goe downe into the pit. But is not this a Å¿trange Å¿peech in David, as though there were a grave of the Soule, as there is of the Body? for if there be not, how then is it true, that God hath brought up his Å¿oule from the Grave? Is it perhaps, that he calls it the Soule, which is but the cementing of the Body, and life together? or that he calls it the Grave of the Soule, when it is in the loweÅ¿t eÅ¿tate of vivifying the Body? What ever it be, it Å¿hewes a great mercy in God, and a great power of that mercy, to raiÅ¿e him up, that was brought Å¿o low, and to keepe him from falling into the Pit, that was fallen already to the pits brinke. The truth is, that as Å¿inne is the death of the Soule, Å¿o continuance in Å¿inne, is the grave of the Soule; and in this Grave of continuance, did Davids Å¿oule lye a long time: (Alas! the Å¿horteÅ¿t time, in this caÅ¿e is long) till God by his quickning Spirit, reÅ¿tored him againe to the life of Grace; that hee had juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to Å¿ay; Thou, O Lord, haÅ¿t brought up my Å¿oule from the grave, and haÅ¿t kept mee alive, that I Å¿hould not goe downe into the Pit. Oh how many there are that have bodyes walking above ground, when their Å¿oules are lying in the Grave? that are luÅ¿tie and Å¿trong in the naturall life; when in the Å¿pirituall life, they
are dead and buryed? yet Å¿o long as they lye not buried above foure dayes, Å¿o long as they continue not in Å¿in Å¿o long, till it have brought the Soule into an abÅ¿olute corruption; there is example in Lazarus, and where there is Example, there is hope, they may be raiÅ¿ed againe to life, and be kept from falling into the Pit of perdition. And now, O my Å¿oule, though God have not lifted thee up to as high a place; yet Å¿eeing he hath lifted thee up from as low a place, as he did David: haÅ¿t thou not as juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e as he to Å¿ay; I will extoll thee, O God; for thou haÅ¿t lifted mee up, and haÅ¿t not Å¿uffered my enemies, Å¿inne, and death, to triumph over mee. And here I find my Å¿elfe Å¿o oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with joy, that I am not able to expreÅ¿Å¿e it without aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance; and what aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance can I looke for, but from the Saints of God? O therefore Å¿ing unto the Lord, all yee Å¿aints of his; give thankes unto him at the remembrance of his HolineÅ¿Å¿e. It is not enough to praiÅ¿e him, if yee doe not Å¿ing his praiÅ¿es; for it muÅ¿t be done with chearefulneÅ¿Å¿e, and exultation; and it is not enough to Å¿ing, if yee doe not praiÅ¿e him; for your joy muÅ¿t be in him, and for him: in his goodneÅ¿Å¿e, and for his glory.

If it were to Å¿ing of another thing, I Å¿hould require the whole Quire of Gods creatures, to joyne in the Å¿inging; but now, that it is to Å¿ing of Gods holineÅ¿Å¿e; what Å¿hould prophane voyces doe in the ConÅ¿ort? None but Saints are
fit to Å¿ing of holineÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿pecially of Gods holineÅ¿Å¿e; but moÅ¿t Å¿pecially with Å¿ongs of holineÅ¿Å¿e. O therefore Å¿ing to the Lord, all yee Å¿aints of his; and let your Å¿ongs, be more of his praiÅ¿es, then of your owne thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e: and let your thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e, not be Å¿o much for the benefits which you have received; as for the holineÅ¿Å¿e with which they are beÅ¿towed: for God gives not his benefits, as the world uÅ¿eth to doe, out of any corrupt affection, or with any corrupt intention; but there is a holineÅ¿Å¿e in his giving, as well as in his gifts; and Å¿eeing the Cherubins, and Seraphins doe continually cry to God; Holy, Holy, Holy: You that are his Saints may well afford to Å¿ing to God, at the remembrance of his holineÅ¿Å¿e.

But what holineÅ¿Å¿e can there be in Anger? VerÅ¿e 5 and is there not anger in God Å¿ometimes? and will not this then bee a cauÅ¿e, rather of weeping to thinke of his anger; then of Å¿inging, at the remembrance of his holineÅ¿Å¿e? O my Å¿oule, this need be no cauÅ¿e to breake off the Å¿inging; for his anger endureth but a moment; and even anger it Å¿elfe, is in God a holineÅ¿Å¿e; It is none of the things that are naturall, and permanent in God; It is but forced upon him by the violence of Å¿inne; and as forced as it is, it Å¿tayes not with him; it is but as a wind that paÅ¿Å¿eth; Dum oritur moritur; It dyes in the birth; Nothing lives, and is permanent in God, but onely his favour, and his love, and therefore,
Though weeping may endure for a night, yet joy commeth in the morning. And Å¿eeing our life is of this condition, that heavineÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ometimes muÅ¿t as well be had as joy; it is happy for us, they are Å¿o diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, that heavineÅ¿Å¿e comes but in the Evening, when wee may Å¿leepe it out; and when our Å¿enÅ¿es are apt to be tyed up from feeling it: but joy commeth in the Morning; when all our Å¿enÅ¿es are waking to entertaine it. What is the Evening, but the end of the day? and what is the Evening of our life, but the end of our dayes? and in this Evening indeed there is commonly heavineÅ¿Å¿e; weeping for parting of friends that have lived together: but this heavineÅ¿Å¿e is removed aÅ¿Å¿oone as morning comes; for what is the Morning, but when the Sunne riÅ¿eth againe? and what is our Morning, but when we Å¿hall riÅ¿e againe? and as when this morning comes, there will bee a day that Å¿hall have no more Evening; Å¿o when this joy comes, all teares Å¿hall be wiped from our eyes, and there Å¿hall be no more weeping. Indeed all our great joyes have ever come in the morning: It was a Joy that came in the morning, at the Birth of ChriÅ¿t; It was a Joy that came in the morning, at the ReÅ¿urrection of ChriÅ¿t; It was a Joy that came in the morning, at the DeÅ¿cending of the Holy GhoÅ¿t upon the ApoÅ¿tles; and theÅ¿e Joyes were then Å¿o great, that they have made us FeaÅ¿ts ever Å¿ince: (Our ChriÅ¿tmaÅ¿Å¿e, our EaÅ¿ter, and our WhitÅ¿ontide:)
yet theÅ¿e Joyes had their heavineÅ¿Å¿e preceding: the Joy of ChriÅ¿ts birth, had the heavineÅ¿Å¿e of his Mothers Å¿light; the Joy of ChriÅ¿ts ReÅ¿urrection, had the heavineÅ¿Å¿e for his PaÅ¿Å¿ion: the Joy of the DeÅ¿cending of the Holy GhoÅ¿t, the heavineÅ¿Å¿e for ChriÅ¿ts departing: but theÅ¿e heavineÅ¿Å¿es were Å¿o preÅ¿ently followed with joyes, that it hath made this AphoriÅ¿me be found true Å¿till; HeavineÅ¿Å¿e may endure for a night, but joy commeth in the morning. And now, O my Å¿oule, what need it trouble thee, to have heavineÅ¿Å¿e in the Evening, Å¿o long as thou art Å¿ure to have joy in the morning? What need it trouble thee to be weeping for a time, when thou art Å¿ure of rejoycing, when time Å¿hall be no more?

Hitherto I have beene buÅ¿ie about Å¿inging Gods praiÅ¿es, for lifting mee up, which hath beene his worke; Now I muÅ¿t leave Å¿inging, and come to Å¿aying, to Å¿peake of my owne worke; And I Å¿aid in my proÅ¿peritie, I Å¿hall never VerÅ¿e 6 be moved: but alas, if my Å¿inging were no VerÅ¿e 7 better then my Å¿aying, it had beene better for me, to have held my peace in both: for what a Å¿aying is this, to Å¿ay; I Å¿hall never be moved? Is there any Mountaine Å¿o Å¿trong, that it cannot be moved? and if no Mountaine, how any man? but this is the inÅ¿olent language of proÅ¿peritie, to give over crying to God, and fall a boaÅ¿ting of it Å¿elfe. Alas! ProÅ¿peritie hath neither good tongue, nor good eyes; as it
made David Å¿ay, hee Å¿hould never be moved; Å¿o it made him thinke it enough, that God by his favour had made his Mountaine Å¿trong; but as for the maintaining it Å¿trong, to arrogate that to himÅ¿elfe: when God knowes, if once we leave depending upon God, and arrogate any thing to our Å¿elves, our Mountaine will Å¿oone bee turned into a Valley, and our Å¿trength will goe from us, as it did from SamÅ¿on, when his haire was cut off; and this makes David Å¿ay now; Thou didÅ¿t hide thy face, and I was troubled: for as it is the favour of God, that makes our Mountaine Å¿trong; and our Mountaine being Å¿trong, wee are kept from trouble: Å¿o it is the hiding of Gods face, that makes our moutaine weake; and our mountaine being weake, wee are preÅ¿ently troubled; but rather indeed, if God doe not as well maintaine our mountaine Å¿trong, as make it Å¿trong, we Å¿hall quickly bring our Mountaine to a Mole-hill; wee Å¿hall quickly either fall our Å¿elves from our Mountaine; or have our mountaine to fall upon us.

Wee Å¿ee the Earth hath no comfort but in the Sunne; and therefore if the Sunne bee removed, the Earth preÅ¿ently puts on Blacks; is pincht with cold, and covered with darkneÅ¿Å¿e: That which the Sunne is to the Earth; thy Face, O God, is to me, and what marvell then, when thou hideÅ¿t thy face; if I bee left, as a diÅ¿conÅ¿olate Earth, in trouble and mourning?
God uÅ¿eth not to hide his face from any that depend upon him; and therefore as long as I put my truÅ¿t and confidence in him, he was to me as a Å¿trong Mountain; I enjoyed his favour, and the light of his Countenance; but aÅ¿Å¿oone as I left depending upon him, and truÅ¿ted to my owne Å¿trength, my Mountaine was Å¿uddenly turned into a Valley; and I was left alas in a vale of miÅ¿erie. O therefore, my Å¿oule, notwithÅ¿tanding any proÅ¿peritie whatÅ¿oever; Doe thou depend upon God for thy Mountaine, both for making it Å¿trong, and for maintaing it Å¿trong, and never bee moved to Å¿ay, thou Å¿halt never be moved; for to bee immovable, is a priviledge of God himÅ¿elfe, and of God alone, and is not communicable to any creature. It is a falÅ¿e Å¿aying in any eÅ¿tate to Å¿ay; I Å¿hall never be moved; but in proÅ¿peritie, falÅ¿eÅ¿t of all: for hee that is in proÅ¿peritie, Å¿tands in a Å¿lipperie place, and Å¿uch a place is not capable of Å¿tabilitie. What is proÅ¿peritie but an earthy thing? and can any thing that is earthy be Å¿ecure from moving, when the body of the Earth it Å¿elfe is moved? O my Å¿oule, the conÅ¿ideration of this; Alas! the feeling of this hath made mee leave, both Å¿inging, and Å¿aying, and fall to my crying againe: I cryed to thee, O Lord; and unto the Lord I made Å¿upplication:
VerÅ¿e 8 Indeed crying is the voyce of a Å¿uppliant, and the fitteÅ¿t voyce for a Å¿upplication: but yet why Å¿hould David tell God of his
crying to him, and Å¿ay; I cryed to thee, O Lord; as though God knew it not, without his telling it? No doubt, God knew of his crying, for how elÅ¿e did he heare it? and of his Å¿upplication; for how elÅ¿e could hee grant it? and therefore it Å¿eemes, hee tells it not Å¿o much to God, as to us; that wee may take notice, with what Å¿acrifices God is pleaÅ¿ed. For as there are divers Å¿acrifices that are acceptable to God: Å¿o each of them, in the due time, is the fitteÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t acceptable: Å¿inging, fitteÅ¿t after a benefit obtained; and crying, fitteÅ¿t for obtaining a benefit: Allelujahs fitteÅ¿t, when wee are in triumph: HoÅ¿anna's, fitteÅ¿t when we are in diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e. And therefore being at the preÅ¿ent, in perill of his life; and delivered as it were into the hands of Death; the Å¿acrifice he offers now, is a Å¿upplication; which yet Å¿eemes not Å¿o much a Å¿upplication, as an ExpoÅ¿tulation; VerÅ¿e 9 What profit is there in my bloud, when I goe downe into the pit? Å¿hall the duÅ¿t praiÅ¿e thee? Å¿hall it declare thy truth? If I goe downe into the Pit, Å¿hall I not bee turned into duÅ¿t? and is duÅ¿t good for any thing, but to be food for the Serpent? May I not doe thee better Å¿ervice above ground, then under it? Alas! I Å¿hall be there but in the company of Wormes, poore Å¿illy things, that are not capable of knowing thee: I am here, in the Å¿ocietie of reaÅ¿onable creatures, with whom I may joyne in extolling thy PraiÅ¿es. HaÅ¿t thou not breathed
into mee the breath of life, and wilt thou draw in thy breath Å¿o quickly againe, and leave mee but duÅ¿t, as thou foundeÅ¿t me at firÅ¿t? Though the Å¿ervice I can doe thee be not great, yet it is more then duÅ¿t can doe: Hath duÅ¿t a tongue, or a voyce, or any inÅ¿truments of life, for the declaring of thy truth? and why then wilt thou make a divorce of parts, which thou haÅ¿t joyned together of purpoÅ¿e, for that purpoÅ¿e? If I deÅ¿ired life for any end of my owne, thou hadÅ¿t juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e then, to make an end of my life; but now that I deÅ¿ire it, to doe thee Å¿ervice, why wilt thou diminiÅ¿h the number of thy Å¿ervants, and not leave enow for the Å¿ervice thou haÅ¿t to doe? Can any number be Å¿ufficient to praiÅ¿e thee? Can there ever be mouthes enow to declare thy Truth? and may not I make one, a Å¿infull one I know; but yet one in the number, if thou but pleaÅ¿e to Å¿pare mee for deÅ¿cending into the Pit? But what Pit? I meane not the Pit, where the ApoÅ¿tate Angels are; I know they deÅ¿cended not, but fell; and I know the Pit they fell into, is a Pit of blaÅ¿phemie: the Pit I feare deÅ¿cending into, is but a Pit of Å¿ilence, and yet in one thing, is worÅ¿e then theirs; for they in their Pit, retaine their Å¿ubÅ¿tance Å¿till; but I in this, Å¿hall loÅ¿e my very Being; at leaÅ¿t, the quantitas continua of my body, Å¿hall bee turned into the quantitas DiÅ¿creta of duÅ¿t: and the frame compacted of all the Elements diÅ¿Å¿olved; I Å¿hall
remaine nothing, but as it were a few crummes of Earth; and what can Earth doe, when it is not aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with fire and water? O therefore, VerÅ¿e 10 Heare, O Lord; and have mercy upon me, Lord, bee thou my helper: for if thou lend mee not thine eare, how can I hope thou wilt Å¿hew mee mercy? and if thou have not mercy upon me, how can I hope thou wilt bee my helper? Heare me, O God, while I am in a place, where I may be heard; for if once I be deÅ¿cended into the Pit, I Å¿hall quite then be out of all hearing. Have mercy upon me, while I am capable of mercy; for if once I be turned into duÅ¿t, what mercy can I looke for? Be thou my helper, O God, now that I am in a Å¿tate to bee helped; for if my bloud in which my life conÅ¿iÅ¿ts bee once Å¿hed; what good then will thy helpe doe me? I place Gods mercy in the midÅ¿t here, becauÅ¿e it muÅ¿t Å¿erve to both the other; both to make God to heare me, and to make him to helpe me: and Gods mercy can doe both; it can make him to heare me, though I were Å¿ilent; and can make him to helpe me, though I were duÅ¿t. But though Gods mercy can doe it, am I Å¿ure it will doe it? O my Å¿oule, his mercy hath done it already: for it is the worke of his mercy, that Hee hath turned my mourning into dauncing, that hee hath put off my Å¿ackcloth, and girded mee with gladneÅ¿Å¿e. O wonderfull converÅ¿ion; the very Å¿ame myracle, I may Å¿ay, that ChriÅ¿t wrought at the Mariage in
Cana, for to turne Mourning into Dauncing; what is it, but to turne water into Wine? To have turned my mourning, but into comfort, had beene a great worke, and a great favour: but to turne my mourning into dauncing; the extremitie of Å¿orrow, into extremitie of joy; who could doe this, but thou onely, O God; with whom, as no Myracles are wonders; Å¿o no extremities are limits. Mourning is not properly, but for one that is dead: and indeed Å¿o neere being dead was I, that I might well be Å¿aid to mourne for my owne death: not unlike the Swan; if it be true, that Å¿hee Å¿ings her owne Elegie: and now to have my mourning turned into dauncing; the drooping act for Death, be turned into the moÅ¿t lively act of Life: what is it, but the Myracle, as it were, of ReÅ¿urrection, and AÅ¿cention both at once? at leaÅ¿t, from the loweÅ¿t Å¿tayre of miÅ¿erie, to be raiÅ¿ed to the higheÅ¿t of happineÅ¿Å¿e: and not Gradatim, by degrees and Å¿teps, but per Å¿altum, by a motion more Å¿wift, than the Fiery Chariot, that carried up Elias into Heaven: and Å¿o the change not more wonderfull, then the Å¿uddenneÅ¿Å¿e; Mourning turned into Dauncing, a wonderfull change; and done, as it were, in the turning of a hand, as wonderfull a Å¿uddenneÅ¿Å¿e.

And now to make me fit for Dauncing; Thou haÅ¿t put off my Å¿ackcloth, and girded me with gladneÅ¿Å¿e: for indeed, if I had kept on my Å¿ackcloth Å¿till; I Å¿hould have made but a heavie
Dauncer; but now, that my Å¿ackcloth is off, and I am girded with gladneÅ¿Å¿e; I Å¿hall leape as light, as Abraham did, to Å¿ee thy day.

I put on Å¿ackcloth when I was a Mourner; but now that I am to be a Dauncer, I am girded with gladneÅ¿s: and if I mourned before, to think of Gods anger; may I not juÅ¿tly daunce now, to thinke of his favour? If I put on Å¿ackcloth before, as Å¿orrowing for my Å¿inne; may I not juÅ¿tly now be girded with gladneÅ¿Å¿e, as rejoycing in my Saviour? For though it be Gods mercy, that hath done this for me, yet it is his mercy in ChriÅ¿t my Saviour: without whom, his mercy alone would never have done it: He would never have put off my Å¿ackcloth, and girded me with gladneÅ¿Å¿e, but for his Å¿ake, and through his meanes, that was anoynted with the Oyle of gladneÅ¿Å¿e above his fellowes. My Å¿ackcloth was but a looÅ¿e garment about mee, which might eaÅ¿ily be put off at pleaÅ¿ure, but my gladneÅ¿Å¿e is girt about me, to bee faÅ¿t and Å¿ure, and cannot leave me, though it would; at leaÅ¿t, none Å¿hall be able to take it from me.

And now, though this be Å¿poken here in the caÅ¿e of David, yet it may bee conceived as in Type for all the godly: if they mourne, and lye in Å¿ackcloth now; yet they Å¿hall ere long be girded with GladneÅ¿Å¿e, and daunce for joy; but what Dauncing? Not like that of Herodias Daughter; for which Herod allowed her to aske halfe his Kingdome; but like that of David
before the Arke; for which God without asking, will give us a whole Kingdome. And when Å¿hall the time bee? Alas! it cannot be long: For they Å¿hall not goe out of Egypt into Canaan, as the old IÅ¿raelites did, by the tedious paÅ¿Å¿ages of a troubleÅ¿ome WilderneÅ¿Å¿e; but their Mourning Å¿hall be turned into Dauncing: a converÅ¿ion as Å¿udden, as when MoÅ¿es his Leprous hand was turned to be Å¿ound againe, by putting it onely in his boÅ¿ome.

But to what end is it, that God hath done VerÅ¿e 12 this for me? It may be thought, becauÅ¿e hee hath turned my Mourning into Dauncing, and hath girded me with GladneÅ¿Å¿e; that hee hath done it to this end, that I might live in jollity, and Å¿pend my time with BelÅ¿hazzar, in revelling and feaÅ¿ting: but there is no Å¿uch matter: hee hath done it to this end, that my glory may Å¿ing praiÅ¿e unto him, and not bee Å¿ilent: to this end, that not onely I may praiÅ¿e him, but may Å¿ing his praiÅ¿es; and not onely that I, but that my glory may Å¿ing them; and alas what glory have I? doth not all glory belong to God? Indeed Å¿o it is, my glory then Å¿ings his PrayÅ¿es, when I aÅ¿cribe to him all praiÅ¿e and glory; my glory then Å¿ings his prayÅ¿es, when I praiÅ¿e him with all I have to glory in, with all the faculties and powers of my Å¿oule and body; thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially in which I was made after his Image, for this is my Glory.

If this then bee the end that God intends,
Å¿hall I be Å¿o ungratefull, to croÅ¿Å¿e his intentions? if hee have given mee a Tongue, and a Voyce to Å¿erve him; Å¿hall I hold my peace, and be Å¿ilent in his Å¿ervice? if he have turned my Mourning into Dauncing; Å¿hall I bee Å¿ullen, and Å¿low to Å¿ing his PrayÅ¿es? Alas! my Dauncing can never be kindly without MuÅ¿ick; and what muÅ¿ick Å¿o fit for it, as Å¿inging? and what Å¿inging Å¿o fit, as to the Ditty of his PrayÅ¿es? O my Å¿oule, Å¿eeing God hath procured thee libertie to Daunce, thou mayÅ¿t well afford to find the muÅ¿ick: and yet neither my Dauncing Å¿hall hearken to the muÅ¿icke, nor my Å¿inging Å¿hall looke toward the Dauncing; but my Singing and my Dauncing both, Å¿hall bee addreÅ¿Å¿ed, and directed to God alone. Shall my heart be Å¿o Å¿et upon my joy, as to make me forget the Authour of my joy? No, O God, my joy hath Å¿o Å¿ure a foundation, that I can never be unmindfull of the Founder: I will give thankes to thee, O Lord, my God, for ever. Not for a time which will ceaÅ¿e; Not as long as the Sunne and Moone endure, which Å¿hall not alwayes endure; not as long as I have breath in my body; No my Å¿oule, but as long as thou thy Å¿elfe haÅ¿t Being; which being breathed into mee by God, Å¿hall never ceaÅ¿e; Å¿hall alwayes endure; Å¿hall be forever.

When I extolled God, I had relation to his Omnipotencie: when I Å¿ung his PrayÅ¿es, to his Mercie; and now that I give him thankes
for ever, to his Eternitie: that now I may conclude, and Å¿ay; O Almightie, moÅ¿t Mercifull, and ever-living God; to thee be aÅ¿cribed all Honour, PrayÅ¿e, and Glory, world without end.

div.head: THE THIRTIE FOVRTH PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 I Will bleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord at all times; his PrayÅ¿e Å¿hall continually bee in my mouth.
2 My Å¿oule Å¿hall make her boaÅ¿t in the Lord; The humble Å¿hall heare thereof, and be glad.

4 I Å¿ought the Lord, and hee heard me; and delivered me from all my feares.
5 They looked unto him, and were lightened; and their faces were not aÅ¿hamed.

6 The poore man cryed, and the Lord heard
him; and Å¿aved him from all his troubles.

21 Evill Å¿hall Å¿lay the wicked; and they that hate the righteous, Å¿hall be deÅ¿olate.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE XXXIV. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
ALas! what a Vow is this that VerÅ¿e 1 David makes here? a Vow which hee is Å¿ure before hand, he cannot keepe: for is it poÅ¿Å¿ible for any man to bleÅ¿Å¿e God at all times? Is there not a time of paine and miÅ¿erie, in which Jobs Wife perÅ¿waded him to curÅ¿e God and dye? and can curÅ¿ing of God, Å¿tand with bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God? O my Å¿oule, I take not my meaÅ¿ure of bleÅ¿Å¿ing God from the laÅ¿t of that wicked Woman; it is not paine; it is not miÅ¿erie; it is not extremitie of paine, or miÅ¿erie, that Å¿hall make mee to breake my Vow in bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God: but if it be thought Å¿o great a matter to bleÅ¿Å¿e God inmiÅ¿ery; I will Å¿tretch my Vow yet further, for I will bleÅ¿Å¿e him for miÅ¿erie: and I may
truly Å¿ay, if it were not for paine, and miÅ¿ery; I Å¿hould want one Å¿peciall Motive for bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God.

But yet there is a time of Å¿leepe, which is a tribute due to Nature; and is it poÅ¿Å¿ible to pay the tribute of Å¿leepe to Nature, and the tribute of bleÅ¿Å¿ing to God, both at once? If then Å¿leepe be of neceÅ¿Å¿itie Å¿o oftentimes, how can bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God be performed at all times? O my Å¿oule, when our waking is terminated with bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God; that bleÅ¿Å¿ing is in force till we wake againe: for as in what place the tree falleth, there it lyeth: Å¿o in what Å¿tate the Soule goes to reÅ¿t, in that Å¿tate it reÅ¿teth: If my Å¿oule Å¿ay to God; I will lay mee downe to Å¿leepe, for it is Thou, Lord, onely that Å¿uÅ¿taineÅ¿t me; my Å¿oule Å¿hall have it returned from God; Thus the Lord giveth his beloved Å¿leepe.

But if thus perhaps be made good the continuance of BleÅ¿Å¿ing God: yet in what conÅ¿iÅ¿ts the worke of bleÅ¿Å¿ing him? Is it onely in Thought, or onely in a good intention? No my Å¿oule; his praiÅ¿e Å¿hall continually bee in my mouth: for though the heart indeed bee the Fountaine of bleÅ¿Å¿ing him: yet out of the abundance of the heart, the mouth Å¿peaketh; and therefore it Å¿hall not be cloyÅ¿tered up in the Cells of Å¿ilence, but it Å¿hall have vent, and bee brought into the light; that if it bee not Å¿aid, that men Å¿eeing my good workes, it may at leaÅ¿t be Å¿aid, that men hearing my good words,
may glorifie our Father which is in Heaven. But doe I not by this, fall againe upon my old difficultie? for if it Å¿eemed impoÅ¿Å¿ible before to bleÅ¿Å¿e God at all times, may it not juÅ¿tly Å¿eeme as impoÅ¿Å¿ible now, that his PraiÅ¿e Å¿hould continually be in my mouth? It may perhaps be true of the Angels, in whoÅ¿e mouthes wee know of nothing there is continually, but Holy, Holy, Holy, Lord God of Sabbath: but to be verefied of the mouthes of men, Å¿eemes a thing impoÅ¿Å¿ible; for is there not a neceÅ¿Å¿itie of Å¿peaking many things, beÅ¿ides Gods praiÅ¿es? yet nothing muÅ¿t bee Å¿poken, but either his PraiÅ¿e, or to his praiÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e wee breake our Vow.
