It is a Feare that is joyned with Joy: a Feare, not to offend: but a Joy, for not offending: It is a Feare, not Å¿o much of Gods juÅ¿tice, as of his Mercy: for there is mercy with him that hee may bee feared: It is not a Feare that will Å¿horten your life, but be a meanes to prolong it: but then it muÅ¿t not be a bare Å¿peculative feare, but you muÅ¿t put it in practiÅ¿e: and theÅ¿e may bee the rules: Keepe thy tongue from evill, and thy lippes VerÅ¿e 12 from Å¿peaking guile: Depart from evill, and do good: Å¿eeke peace, and purÅ¿ue it. Long life was once
promiÅ¿ed before, to them that honour their Parents; and here it is promiÅ¿ed againe to them that love their Neighbours; for theÅ¿e Rules are as the whole body of morall PhiloÅ¿ophie, and are therefore delivered in Å¿ixe parts, like the Å¿ix Commandements of the Å¿econd Table; which onely concerne our dutie to Neighbours: and in all of them the qualitie of chiefe Predominance, and which keepes then all in tune, is Feare; Keepe thy tongue from evill, for feare of the evill that may enÅ¿ue: and thy lips from Å¿peaking guile, for feare leÅ¿t thy guile bee diÅ¿covered to thy Å¿hame. Depart from evill; for feare of infecting: and doe good, for feare of repenting: Seeke peace, for feare of wanting it; and purÅ¿ue it, for feare of loÅ¿ing it. The two firÅ¿t Precepts are the dutie of words, for words muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be regulated, before workes can bee actuated; and they are both Negative; Keepe thy tongue from evill: and thy lips from Å¿peaking guile: for it is not required of the tongue to be Eloquent; or of the lips to deliver Oracles: It is enough in the tongue, if it be not irreverent to Å¿uperiours, nor detracting from equalls: It is enough in the lips, if they be not charmes to deceive, nor Equivocations to delude.

The other Precepts are the dutie of workes, and they are foure; where the Precepts of words were but two; becauÅ¿e we muÅ¿t be more in workes, then in words: and they are all Affirmative: for it is againÅ¿t the nature of a worke,
to be in the Negative: for Å¿o working Å¿hould be no better then idleneÅ¿Å¿e: the two former are generall, as generall as Good and Evill; that if we meet with any thing that is Evill, our part is to Depart: for there is no demurring upon Evill; No dallying with baytes: leÅ¿t Å¿taying, we be Å¿tayed, as Eve was: Therefore depart from evill. If we meet with any thing that is good; our worke is, to fall a working; for vertue conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in action, and is not Å¿o proper to bee talked of, as to be done: we never reade of any reward for good words onely; but all reward is onely for good workes: BecauÅ¿e thou haÅ¿t done this; Å¿aith God to Abraham: Therefore doe good. The two laÅ¿t Precepts are Å¿peciall; whither we call them Å¿peciall, as being particular, or as being excellent, for Å¿o is Peace: It is the legacie that was left us by ChriÅ¿t: and who would loÅ¿e ChriÅ¿ts Legacie, for want of Å¿eeking it? Therefore Å¿eeke Peace, and purÅ¿ue it: but not purÅ¿ue Peace, for this were to make warre upon peace, but purÅ¿ue the Å¿eeking of Peace: for though it be Å¿aid; Å¿eeke, and yee Å¿hall find; yet it is not Å¿aid how long we muÅ¿t Å¿eeke before wee Å¿hall find: if therefore Å¿eeking Peace, you find it not at firÅ¿t, purÅ¿ue the Å¿eeking it, and you Å¿hall find it at laÅ¿t. Agree with thine AdverÅ¿arie while thou art in the way; This is to Å¿eeke peace: Leave thine offering at the Altar, and goe firÅ¿t, and be reconciled: This is to purÅ¿ue it, Or perhaps the counÅ¿ell that Saint Paul gives
to Timothy, may expreÅ¿Å¿e it plainer: Be inÅ¿tant in Å¿eaÅ¿on, and out of Å¿eaÅ¿on: to bee inÅ¿tant in Å¿eaÅ¿on, is to Å¿eeke peace: to be inÅ¿tant out of Å¿eaÅ¿on, is to purÅ¿ue it. Indeed if a man deÅ¿ire long life, and to Å¿ee good dayes; he muÅ¿t have a Å¿peciall care of peace: whither it be peace in the humours, or peace in the PaÅ¿Å¿ions; whither Peace with God, or peace with men: they are all prolongers of life; and life is never Å¿hortened or diÅ¿quieted, but for want of peace in one of theÅ¿e, and therefore that you may not bee to Å¿eeke of long life; Å¿eeke peace, and purÅ¿ue it.

And now, O my Å¿oule, is there not great cauÅ¿e, that the feare of the Lord Å¿hould animate all our words and workes, when Å¿o great a MajeÅ¿tie, as the eye of God is looking upon them? when Å¿o Å¿acred an Auditorie, as the VerÅ¿e 15 eares of God are hearkening to them? For the eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous; and his eares are open to their cry; and can any man be Å¿o without Å¿hame, as to bee without feare, when he is the Å¿pectacle which God is pleaÅ¿ed to looke upon? the Å¿peaker which he vouchÅ¿afes to hearken to? But, O my Å¿oule, as it cannot but make thee feare, Å¿o it cannot but make thee joy; for what greater honour, then to bee the object of Gods eyes and eares? What though the world regard thee not, as long as God regards thee? What are the eyes and eares of the world, but eyes and eares of Å¿corne, or elÅ¿e of envie: of Å¿corne, when in adverÅ¿itie, and of
envie in proÅ¿peritie? but the eyes of the Lord, are righteous eyes, and are therefore upon the righteous: his eares, are eares of compaÅ¿Å¿ion, and therefore are open to their cry. But are not the Eyes of the Lord, as well upon the wicked? and what priviledge then is this to the Righteous? No my Å¿oule, his Eyes are upon the Righteous, but they are againÅ¿t the wicked; and not onely his eyes, but his whole Face is againÅ¿t them, to cut off their remembrance VerÅ¿e 16 from the earth: O my Å¿oule, as thou conÅ¿idereÅ¿t with joy, the great force that is in righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, which drawes the eyes, and opens the eares of God: Å¿o conÅ¿ider with trembling, the great force that is in Å¿inne, which not onely turnes away his Eyes, and Å¿tops his Eares, but makes him to bend his whole Face in furie; that if his favours of looking upon us, and hearkening to us, cannot winne us to feare him out of love: at leaÅ¿t the bending his Face againÅ¿t us in anger, may force us to feare him out of terrour: for he bends not his Face to make a Å¿hew onely, as though he did but Å¿et a face upon it; but it is to cut off the very remembrance of them that doe evill from the Earth.

But how is it like to be true, that the godly Å¿hall never be forgotten, when they Å¿eeme to be forgotten already while they live? for how elÅ¿e Å¿hould it happen, that they are more in trouble, in more trouble than other men, but that God hath caÅ¿t them out of his remembrance? O my Å¿oule, their very being in trouble,
is a certaine argument that God remembers them: if he had not remembred Job, and his righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, he would never have given Sathan Å¿o much leave as he did to trouble him. For indeed, though troubles be judgements to the wicked; and are as the firÅ¿t blowes to cut off their remembrance from the earth, yet they are but tryals to the godly, and doe but Å¿erve to make their remembrance be the freÅ¿her. Doe we not Å¿ee how Trees are nipt with froÅ¿t and cold, and not Å¿o much as a leafe left hanging upon them, Å¿carce Å¿o much as life remaining in them? but is it not to renue in them the freÅ¿her Å¿pringing, and to make way for fruits in a greater plentie? and Å¿uch are the troubles of the godly, they end in deliverance; and though they be bitter for the preÅ¿ent, yet they make the joyes afterward to taÅ¿te the Å¿weeter. And what marvell, if God heare the cry of the righteous, being Å¿o nigh unto them as hee is? For the Lord is nigh unto them, that are of a broken VerÅ¿e 18 heart: Not broken with envie, as many are: Not broken with deÅ¿paire, as Å¿ome are; but broken with Å¿enÅ¿e of their Å¿inne, as the righteous are; for this onely is the broken heart, to which God is nigh: and hee is not nigh it, in vaine: No my Å¿oule, it is good having God to be our neighbour; for hee Å¿aves all them to whom he is nigh; Hee Å¿aves all them that bee of a contrite, and humble heart: the lower they are in their owne eyes, the higher they are in his:
and when their heart is broken with Å¿enÅ¿e of their Å¿inne, he makes it whole againe with Å¿upply VerÅ¿e 19 of his grace. It is true; Many are the afflictions of the righteous; but the Lord delivers them out of all. For the righteous have many enemies, and therefore muÅ¿t needes have many troubles; but their troubles are not troubleÅ¿ome, becauÅ¿e they have the Lord for their deliverer; if it be Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, he makes their bed, in their Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e: If it be hunger, hee fills the hungrie with good things, when hee Å¿ends the rich emptie away: if it be Death it Å¿elfe; Domini, Domini Å¿unt exitus mortis; the iÅ¿Å¿ues of Death are all in Gods hands: and all this while, though their heart be broken, yet their bones are whole Å¿till: They may have thornes in the fleÅ¿h, but not a bone of theirs is broken: for one of VerÅ¿e 20 their bones is Faith, which though it may bee Å¿haken, yet it cannot bee broken: Another of their bones is Hope, which though it may bee battered, yet it cannot be broken: and Patience is a bone, which may be vexed, but can never be broken: for in all of them, the Lord hath a hand; Hee upholds the righteous, that they cannot fall: Hee Å¿trengthens them that they cannot faint, and as long as their bones bee whole, they are able to Å¿tand upright, and Å¿hrinke not for any burthen, that either the FleÅ¿h, or the World can lay upon them. And though David in this, have an eye perhaps upon ChriÅ¿t, of whom indeed there was not a
Bone broken; yet what is Å¿poken of the Head, may not incongruouÅ¿ly bee applyed to the Members: and in the Å¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e of ChriÅ¿ts bones, the bones of the godly are kept from breaking. But the troubles of the wicked are of another nature; for, Evill Å¿hall Å¿lay the wicked; VerÅ¿e 21 and they that hate the righteous Å¿hall be deÅ¿olate. Their hearts perhaps are broken too, but becauÅ¿e they are not broken with Å¿enÅ¿e of their Å¿inne, but with Å¿pight and malice to the Righteous, there Å¿hall be none to make them whole, but their owne evill, Å¿hall be their owne deÅ¿truction; and having none to deliver them, they Å¿hall be left deÅ¿olate, and without all hope of helpe. But Å¿hall not the wicked then have this good by being deÅ¿olate, that as they have none to helpe them, Å¿o they have none to hurt them? Alas! it needes not, they doe it faÅ¿t enough themÅ¿elves; for Sinne is a recoyling PoyÅ¿on; it turnes violently backe upon them that commit it: and it may be truly Å¿aid of every wicked man, that he is Felo de Å¿e, a Murtherer of himÅ¿elfe. Though RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of it Å¿elfe, doth not Å¿ave the Righteous, but they need a Saviour beÅ¿ides; yet wickedneÅ¿Å¿e of it Å¿elfe deÅ¿troyes the wicked, they need no other DeÅ¿troyer: Perditio tua ex te, O IÅ¿rael; Thy deÅ¿truÅ¿tion is from thy Å¿elfe, O IÅ¿rael.

And, O my Å¿oule, what great Examples there are to verefie this Å¿aying; They that hate the righteous, Å¿hall be deÅ¿olate. When Cain hated
the righteous Abel, was he not thereupon made deÅ¿olate, and became a Vagabond, forÅ¿aken both of God and man? but in a higher degree; when the wicked Jewes hated ChriÅ¿t the righteous, was there not a Voyce heard as of Angels, Å¿aying; Migremus hinc: Let us depart from this place? and thereupon left them deÅ¿olate, without Prince, or Prophet; without Temple, or Altar, to this day? You may Å¿ay perhaps, that Cain might eaÅ¿ily be made deÅ¿olate, having killed his brother in a time, when there was no more in the whole world, but that one Familie: but how can the wicked bee made deÅ¿olate now, when Totus mundus in maligno eÅ¿t poÅ¿itus; When all the world is full of them; and no BeaÅ¿ts Å¿o herd together as they doe? But is it not, that DeÅ¿olateneÅ¿Å¿e conÅ¿iÅ¿ts not Å¿o much in want of company, as in want of comfort: was Job the leÅ¿Å¿e deÅ¿olate for having company, of whom to Å¿ay; MiÅ¿erable comforters are ye all? much leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hal the wicked be the leÅ¿Å¿e deÅ¿olate for having company of whom to Å¿ay; MiÅ¿erable Tormentours are yee all: for alas, all their companie, Å¿hall bee either Companions in their torments, or Companions their tormentours: which can never bee the caÅ¿e of the godly: for though they be not Å¿o perfect, not to have their faults, yet they are Å¿o happy, not to have them imputed: for being Gods Å¿ervants, Hee will redeeme them: though they be taken captive, yet hee will not
Å¿uffer them to continue Captives: but rather then not redeeme them, he will give his onely Sonne to be their ranÅ¿ome.

But yet how can the godly chooÅ¿e but bee DeÅ¿olate, when the whole world Å¿carce affords enow to make a company? and where then can company be had to keepe them from being deÅ¿olate? O my Å¿oule, they have Angels to pitch their Tents about them, while they live here, and hereafter they Å¿hall come to bee Citizens in the New HieruÅ¿alem, where they Å¿hall have company enough: PrieÅ¿ts, and Patriarks; Prophets, and ApoÅ¿tles; Martyrs, and ConfeÅ¿Å¿ours; bleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgins, and chiefly the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin; but above all, where they Å¿hall Å¿ee the BleÅ¿Å¿ed face of God; whoÅ¿e onely Å¿ight is able; whoÅ¿e Å¿ight is onely able to keepe from being deÅ¿olate: and then at leaÅ¿t I Å¿hall bee as able to performe my Vow, as now I am ready to make it: I will bleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord at all times; his PraiÅ¿e Å¿hall continually be in my mouth.

div.head: THE EIGHTIE FOVRTH PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 HOw amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of hoÅ¿ts!
2 My Å¿oule longeth; yea, even fainteth for the Courts of the Lord: My heart, and my fleÅ¿h, cryeth out for the living God.
3 Yea, the Sparrow hath found an houÅ¿e; and the Swallow a neÅ¿t for her Å¿elfe, where Å¿hee may lay her young: even thine Altars, O Lord of Hosts, my King, and my God.
4 BleÅ¿Å¿ed are they that dwell in thy houÅ¿e; they will be Å¿till prayÅ¿ing thee.

5 BleÅ¿Å¿ed is the man whoÅ¿e Å¿trength is in
thee; and in whoÅ¿e heart are thy wayes.
6 Who paÅ¿sing thorow the valley of Baca, make it a Well: the raine alÅ¿o filleth the pooles.
7 They goe from Å¿trength, to Å¿trength; every one of them in Syon appeareth before God.
8 O Lord God of hoÅ¿ts, heare my prayer; Give eare, O God of Iacob.
9 Behold, O God, our Å¿hield; and looke upon the face of thine Anoynted.
10 For a day in thy Courts, is better then a thouÅ¿and: I had rather be a doore keeper in the houÅ¿e of my God, then to dwell in the tents of wickedneÅ¿Å¿e.
11 For the Lord God is a Sunne and a Å¿hield; The Lord will give grace and glory; No good thing will hee with-hold from them that walke uprightly.
12 O Lord of HoÅ¿ts; BleÅ¿Å¿ed is the man that truÅ¿teth in thee.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE LXXXIV. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
WHen wee cannot expreÅ¿Å¿e the VerÅ¿e 1 greatneÅ¿Å¿e of a thing in direct tearmes; wee are faine to flye to wonder, and Å¿o doth David here; becauÅ¿e he cannot expreÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ufficiently how amiable the Tabernacles of the Lord are; hee therefore falls to wondering, and helpes himÅ¿elfe with a queÅ¿tion: How amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts? But is not Davids wondering it Å¿elfe wonderfull, that the Tabernacles of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts Å¿hould be Å¿o wonderfully amiable? Is it not a wonder they Å¿hould bee amiable at all? For are not his Tabernacles, Tents of Warre? and is there any thing in Warre that can be amiable? If he had Å¿aid; How terrible are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts; his wonder had beene with Å¿ome congruitie: for
the Lord of HoÅ¿ts is terrible in all his workes: but to Å¿ay, How amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts; Å¿eeme to imply a contradiction: for though they may be amiable, as they are Tabernacles; yet they muÅ¿t needs bee terrible, as they are Tabernacles of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts: and when this TerribleneÅ¿Å¿e hath made an abatement in their AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e: What place will be left for wonder, to give cauÅ¿e to Å¿ay; How amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts? But if hee had Å¿ayd; How terrible are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts; though it might have beene wonderfull in the degree, yet it could not bee wonderfull in the kind: for what wonder is it, if the Tabernacles of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts bee terrible? but when he Å¿aith; How amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of HoÅ¿ts; this is not onely wonderfull in the degree; but in the kind, much more. For what can be more wonderfull, then that being Tabernacles of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts, they Å¿hould be amiable, and Å¿o amiable, as to be wondred at? But is it not, that God is in himÅ¿elfe Å¿o amiable, that all things of His, even his Terrours themÅ¿elves are amiable: his Tabernacles and his Tents; his Sword, and his Speare; his Darts, and his Arrowes; all amiable: Terrible no doubt to his Enemies; but amiable, wonderfull amiable to all that love and feare him: and great reaÅ¿on they Å¿hould be Å¿o; Å¿eeing they are all in their defence,
and for their Å¿afeguard: though they be Tabernacles of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts to the wicked, yet they are Courts of the Prince of peace to the godly: and this makes my Å¿oule to VerÅ¿e 2 long for the courts of the Lord. For I deÅ¿ire indeed to be a Courtier, yet not as I am now; God knowes I am very unfit for it: but becauÅ¿e Gods Courts are Å¿uch, they make any one fit, that but comes into them: they receive not men fit, but make them fit; and he that was before, but a Å¿hrub in Baca; aÅ¿Å¿oone as hee comes into the Courts of the Lord, is preÅ¿ently made a Cedar in Lebanon.

Indeed, if his Tabernacles bee Å¿o wonderfull amiable; they muÅ¿t needs be as wonderfull attractive, for there is no Å¿uch Adamant as AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e: Nothing that Å¿o powerfully attracts, and drawes all hearts unto it. And to know the meaÅ¿ure of their AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e, by the power of their Attracting, you need but looke upon my Å¿oule: For, my Å¿oule longeth, and even fainteth for the Courts of the Lord: which it would never doe, if it were not for their wonderfull amiableneÅ¿Å¿e, that attracts, and drawes it by a kind of violence, indeed by a kind violence unto them.

Every AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e is not Å¿o great to make a longing: Nor every longing Å¿o great, to make a fainting: Nor every fainting Å¿o great, to make the Å¿oule to faint: Oh then conÅ¿ider, how great this AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e is, which makes
my Å¿oule not onely to long, but to faint with longing? And blame me not for fainting, as though it were my owne fault, that would not reÅ¿traine my longing: for Å¿eeing his Tabernacles are of infinite amiableneÅ¿Å¿e, they muÅ¿t needs worke in me an infinite delighting; and that delighting, an infinite longing: and what reÅ¿traint can there be of that which is infinite? No alas, my fainting is but anÅ¿werable to my longing, and my longing but anÅ¿werable to the AmiableneÅ¿Å¿e: If I had the offer made me, which was made to ChriÅ¿t, to enjoy all the Kingdomes of the Earth, but with condition to want the Courts of the Lord; this want would bring to my Å¿oule a greater griefe, then that enjoying, would give it contentment: for Å¿eeing his Tabernacles are Å¿o amiable, where he is Lord of HoÅ¿ts; how amiable muÅ¿t they needs be, where hee is Prince of Peace? and Prince of Peace he is in his Courts, though in his Campe he be Lord of HoÅ¿ts.

And that you may know it is not the weakneÅ¿Å¿e of my Å¿oule, that it faints with longing: (for indeed weake Å¿pirits are apt to faint upon every light occaÅ¿ion) but that it is the very operation of the wonderfull attractive power, that is in the amiableneÅ¿Å¿e of his Courts: Å¿ee my Heart, and my FleÅ¿h alÅ¿o, how they are drawne to long after the Lord, which they would never doe, if it were not for Å¿ome wonderfull amiableneÅ¿Å¿e that is in him: for you
may well thinke, it muÅ¿t bee an Adamant of a wonderfull attractive power, that can draw theÅ¿e heavy I rons of my heart, and my fleÅ¿h unto it: for indeed, though my Soule have a longing for the Courts of the Lord, yet my Body perhaps could be content to want them; there are Courts in the world, that might pleaÅ¿e my Body as well; perhaps better then theÅ¿e, but God forbid: God forbid I Å¿hould be one, to have my Å¿oule and body divided while they are united, to have my Å¿oule runne one way, and my body another: No, I am none of thoÅ¿e; but aÅ¿Å¿oone as my Å¿oule longed for the Courts of the Lord; My heart, and my fleÅ¿h fell a longing for the living God: As my Soule longed for the Place, Å¿o my heart, and my fleÅ¿h, for the PerÅ¿on: for my heart, and my fleÅ¿h, are of a duller apprehenÅ¿ion; they muÅ¿t have a preÅ¿ent Enjoying of that they long for, or they cannot be Å¿atisfied: but my Å¿oule is of a cleerer Å¿ight, and knows if it can but come to the place where he is, it Å¿hall be Å¿ure withall, to enjoy his preÅ¿ence, and with his preÅ¿ence, his PerÅ¿on. The Soule indeed is a Å¿pirituall Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and therefore it is natural to the Å¿oule, to long after Å¿piritual things; but the fleÅ¿h is an earthly Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and therefore it is naturall to the fleÅ¿h, to long after earthly things: and as long as theÅ¿e two are linked in the Body together, they will alwayes be working upon one another, alwayes Å¿eeking to draw each other to their partie: and
if the Soule can draw the fleÅ¿h, to goe her Å¿pirituall way, then all is well: it is as it Å¿hould be: but if the FleÅ¿h draw the Soule to goe her earthly way, then all is out of order; there will be no longing for the Courts of the Lord, for they are Å¿pirituall, and are never longed for, but where the Soule is predominant, and hath the leading. And this is the order in Davids longing: firÅ¿t his Soule begins to long for the Courts of the Lord; and this is yet but a Å¿ingle cord: but then comes in, the Heart, and the FleÅ¿h too; and make it a Cord of three, that is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to bee broken. Indeed the Courts of the Lord are Å¿o exceeding amiable, that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible, but every Å¿oule muÅ¿t needs long after them: but yet every Å¿oule conÅ¿iders not what belongs to this longing: but as Balaam longed to dye the death of the Righteous, yet was loath to live the life of the Righteous; Å¿o there are many that long for the Courts of the Lord, but are loath to live the life of Å¿uch Courtiers. They that be in Kings houÅ¿es, weare Å¿ilke, and Å¿oft rayment, becauÅ¿e Å¿o it is fit for the honour of the place; and they that will be in the Courts of the Lord, muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e weare rayment, that is fit for the holineÅ¿Å¿e of the place: they muÅ¿t be cloathed with the Å¿oft rayment of meekneÅ¿Å¿e, and humilitie; they muÅ¿t put on the robe of RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and the garment of Sinceritie; or becauÅ¿e they are Courts of the Lord of HoÅ¿ts: their cloathing
muÅ¿t rather be in Armour, as Saint Paul expreÅ¿Å¿eth it; they muÅ¿t take the Å¿hield of Faith, the Helmet of Salvation, and the Sword of the Spirit; and if they come thus Cloathed, and thus Armed, they may juÅ¿tly then be Å¿aid, to long for the Courts of the Lord: but if they weare not theÅ¿e garmens, their longing will prove but a falÅ¿e conception, and they Å¿hall heare it Å¿aid: Friend, what makeÅ¿t thou here, without a Wedding garment?

If my God were, as the Gods of the Heathen, that have bodyes, but live not; that have eares, but heare not; my heart, and my fleÅ¿h, would then never cry after him, that could not heare them: but now that he is a living God, and hath eares to heare; how can they now forbeare to cry after him, that cannot be without him? for alas, if hee Å¿hould leave them, what would become of them? what would my heart be, but as a dead corps; and what would my fleÅ¿h be, but as the Coffin?

Thou affordeÅ¿t, O Lord, thy meaneÅ¿t creatures, VerÅ¿e 3 their places of reÅ¿t and pleaÅ¿ure; The Sparrow hath found an houÅ¿e; and the Swallow a neÅ¿t for her Å¿elfe, where Å¿hee may lay her young: and wilt thou not afford me to enjoy thine Altars, the onely places of reÅ¿t and pleaÅ¿ure to my Å¿oule? Alas! O Lord, if thou wilt not afford me thine Altars, for places of pleaÅ¿ure; at leaÅ¿t afford them to me for places of Devotion; that if I cannot make them a NeÅ¿t for
my young ones; my humble Meditations, and my penitent Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ions; at leaÅ¿t I may offer upon them, the Å¿acrifices of Prayer, of praiÅ¿e, and ThankÅ¿-giving.

I knew before by thy Courts, thou wert a King; and now I know by thine Altars, thou art a God; that confidently now I can Å¿ay; O Lord of HoÅ¿ts, my King, and my God: that if I feared thee before, as Lord of HoÅ¿ts; I honour thee more now as my King: and adore thee more yet as my God; which as they are to thee, the tender of my dutifulneÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o they are no leÅ¿Å¿e to me, the meanes of my bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: VerÅ¿e 4 For bleÅ¿Å¿ed are they that dwell in thy houÅ¿e, they will Å¿till be praiÅ¿ing thee.

But alas, how happens this? There were Tabernacles before, as belonging to a Lord; and Courts, as belonging to a King; and Altars, as belonging to a God: and now to be but a HouÅ¿e, as belonging to a private man? and Å¿o all this great RiÅ¿ing to end in a Fall? No, my Å¿oule, it is no Fall: it is an aggregation rather of all the other; for where his Tabernacles did but Å¿erve to Å¿hew his Power: his Courts but to Å¿hew his MajeÅ¿tie, his Altars, but to Å¿hew his Deitie; his HouÅ¿e Å¿erves to Å¿hew them all: for in his HouÅ¿e there will bee Å¿till prayÅ¿ing him: and his PraiÅ¿e and Glory is the Å¿umme of all. Or is it, that to dwell in Gods houÅ¿e, is a kind of appropriating him to our Å¿elves, Å¿eeing his Tabernacles, and his Courts, lye open to Å¿trangers;
his HouÅ¿e, open to none but his Å¿ervants: and Å¿eeing in the neereneÅ¿Å¿e to God, and converÅ¿ing with him, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts all true bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e; therefore, BleÅ¿Å¿ed are they that dwell in his HouÅ¿e. But how dwell in it? Not to looke in Å¿ometimes, as we paÅ¿Å¿e by; or to Å¿tay in it a time, as we doe at an Inne; but to be conÅ¿tant abiders in it day and night, as to which we have devoted our Å¿elves, and vowed our Å¿ervice.

But it may be doubted, when David Å¿aith; BleÅ¿Å¿ed are they that dwell in Gods houÅ¿e: What Dwelling it is he meanes; whither dwelling in it, as Tenants, or as Å¿ervants? for if as Tenants, it is like there is Å¿ome Rent to be paid, and there is Å¿mall BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e in paying of Rent: It would be a more bleÅ¿Å¿ed thing, if they could dwell in his HouÅ¿e, and pay him no Rent. If as Å¿ervants, it is like there is Å¿ome worke to bee done, and there is Å¿mall bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e in working: It would be a more bleÅ¿Å¿ed thing, if they could be his Å¿ervants, and doe no worke, and how then comes any BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e in, by dwelling in his HouÅ¿e? Indeed take it either way, let them dwell in his HouÅ¿e as tenants, or as Å¿ervants, and they Å¿hall bee BleÅ¿Å¿ed: let them have Rent to pay, as Tenants; let them have worke to doe, as Å¿ervants, and yet they Å¿hall be bleÅ¿Å¿ed: and that which may Å¿eeme moÅ¿t Å¿trange, the Rent, and the Worke which Å¿eeme to hinder their bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, is the very thing that makes them be bleÅ¿Å¿ed: for they are both
but one thing, both but praiÅ¿ing of God; and praiÅ¿ing of God is the onely thing, that whether they be Tenants, or Servants; whether Bond, or Free, will make them be BleÅ¿Å¿ed.

And yet there is a Dwelling that hath not yet beene thought of; a Dwelling indeed that makes the true BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: and it is, to dwell in Gods houÅ¿e, neither as Tenants, nor yet as Å¿ervants, but as Å¿onnes: for neither Tenants nor Servants, abide in the houÅ¿e for ever, onely the Sonne abideth for ever: and therefore though the HouÅ¿e of God Å¿eeme a meaner Title, then his Tabernacles, and his Courts; yet to us, it is the more comfortable title, Å¿eeing it makes us to be Å¿onnes, which neither his Tabernacles, nor his Courts can doe.

But how appeares it to bee true, that they who dwell in Gods houÅ¿e, wil alwayes be praiÅ¿ing him? Å¿eeing it is but Å¿eldome Å¿eene, that Å¿ervants be Å¿o forward to praiÅ¿e their MaÅ¿ters? O my Å¿oule, it is not Å¿o much the good diÅ¿poÅ¿itions of the Å¿ervants; as the infinite worthineÅ¿Å¿e of the MaÅ¿ter, that makes them to praiÅ¿e him: for when they Å¿ee the admirable O economie of his Government, when they Å¿ee how Å¿weetly he diÅ¿poÅ¿eth all things in weight and meaÅ¿ure, when they find him to uÅ¿e them more like children, then Å¿ervants; what heart can bee Å¿o ungratefull as not to praiÅ¿e him? and Å¿eeing by dwelling in Gods HouÅ¿e, they Å¿ee theÅ¿e things continually; therefore they that dwell in his
HouÅ¿e, will alwayes bee praiÅ¿ing him.

But is it not a Å¿trange reaÅ¿on of BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, to Å¿ay they are bleÅ¿Å¿ed, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿till praiÅ¿ing him? to be praiÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves, might perhaps be Å¿ome bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: but what bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e can it be to praiÅ¿e another? Indeed if that other, were but Å¿uch another as our Å¿elves, it could be none: but when that other is Å¿uch, as that there is not Å¿uch another, or rather not another at all, to praiÅ¿e Å¿uch a one, certainly muÅ¿t needs bee bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, or there can bee none; and Å¿uch a one is God: for alas what are we, but that in him wee live, and move, and have our Being: Hee onely is All in All. O my Å¿oule, if it were not for praiÅ¿ing of God, there had never beene Created Å¿uch a thing as PrayÅ¿e: at leaÅ¿t we may juÅ¿tly Å¿ay, that God, and PrayÅ¿e, are as truly Relatives, as any that are found in either Art, or Nature.

You may Å¿ay then, It is like to bee an eaÅ¿ie matter to be BleÅ¿Å¿ed, if there goe no more to BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, but prayÅ¿ing of God. Marke therefore how David Å¿peakes; They will be Å¿till prayÅ¿ing him. It is not enough to praiÅ¿e him; it muÅ¿t bee a praiÅ¿ing him Å¿till, before it will make a BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, and though to praiÅ¿e God be an eaÅ¿ie matter; yet to praiÅ¿e him Å¿till, will be found a buÅ¿ie worke; indeed to fleÅ¿h and bloud a miÅ¿erable worke; for if I be Å¿till praiÅ¿ing him, what time Å¿hall I have for any pleaÅ¿ure? O my Å¿oule, if thou make it not thy
pleaÅ¿ure, thy chiefe, thy onely pleaÅ¿ure to bee prayÅ¿ing him; thou art not like in haÅ¿t to come to BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e. And marvell not that David Å¿peakes thus under the Law; When Saint Paul under the GoÅ¿pell Å¿aith as much: Whether ye eat, or drinke, or whatÅ¿oever yee doe elÅ¿e; let all be done to the glory, and praiÅ¿e of God. And indeed, how can I doubt of attaining to BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e by praiÅ¿ing of God; when it is praiÅ¿ing of God; that makes the Angels in heaven BleÅ¿Å¿ed? for the Å¿eeing of God, would never make them bleÅ¿Å¿ed, if Å¿eeing him, they did not praiÅ¿e him: and praiÅ¿ing him would never make them bleÅ¿Å¿ed, if they did not praiÅ¿e him continually; crying, Holy, Holy, Holy, Lord God of Sabbath: for as we praiÅ¿e God here on Earth, with Å¿aying, O Lord God of HoÅ¿ts; becauÅ¿e here, he fighteth for us againÅ¿t our enemies; Å¿o wee Å¿hall praiÅ¿e him in heaven with Å¿aying, O Lord God of Sabbath, becauÅ¿e there he will give us reÅ¿t from our enemies.

VerÅ¿e 5 But if it bee thought that praiÅ¿ing of God will not be enough to make BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, or not to make BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e enough; at leaÅ¿t, take this with it, and it will Å¿urely be enough: BleÅ¿Å¿ed is the man whoÅ¿e Å¿trength is in God: and in whoÅ¿e heart his wayes are. For though our praiÅ¿ing of God, being our owne worke muÅ¿t needs be too weake to make a bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e; yet when our Å¿trength is in God, this makes it his worke, and then our bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e hath a Å¿ure foundation.
When we truÅ¿t to our owne Å¿trength for BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, we are often deceived, indeed as often as alwayes; but when our Å¿trength is in God, we may reÅ¿t Å¿ecure; our bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e is upon a Rocke, and cannot be Å¿haken. But then Gods wayes muÅ¿t be in our hearts: for what way hath his Å¿trength to the heart, if his wayes be not in the heart: That's their place, if wee looke for Å¿trength from him. Are we not in a continuall fight againÅ¿t Sin; and have we any Å¿trength to fight, but onely in him? and will he take it well to be placed in a Wing? No my Å¿oule, he will Å¿trengthen us no longer then hee is placed in the heart of the Battell: That's his place, if wee looke to bee Å¿trengthened in him.

It is not enough that Gods wayes bee knowne, if they be not walked in; nor walked in, if not embraced: and it is not enough to embrace them with the armes, which is oftentimes feigned, and but onely complimentall; they muÅ¿t be embraced, with the two armes of the heart; Integritie, and Sinceritie: Integritie will embrace them all; Sinceritie will embrace no other. Though Gods wayes be many, yet they muÅ¿t all goe into one Heart; if any be left out, the reÅ¿t will not tarry; though they muÅ¿t be in Å¿ingleneÅ¿Å¿e of heart, yet they muÅ¿t not be Å¿ingle in the heart; They are fruites that grow in cluÅ¿ters, not one by one.

There are many that have Gods wayes in
their mouthes, can talke holily, and make Sermons of godlineÅ¿Å¿e, though they bee no Preachers; but becauÅ¿e they draw neere to God with their lips, and their hearts, are farre from him; they are like to have but the PhariÅ¿ees entertainment, not Å¿o well juÅ¿tified as the Publican. There are many that have Gods wayes in their hands, they give almes plentifully, they diÅ¿tribute their bread to the Poore liberally; but becauÅ¿e their left hand knowes what their right hand doth; they have their reward already. They that have Gods wayes in their hearts, they onely are in the right way to bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, and no rubbes of the world can turne them out of the way. For when Gods wayes are in the heart together, they lend aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to VerÅ¿e 6 one another; For paÅ¿sing thorow the Valley of Baca, they make it a Well; the raine alÅ¿o filleth the pooles, That which Å¿eemed an impediment turnes to a furtherance; at leaÅ¿t, no miÅ¿ery can be Å¿o great no eÅ¿tate Å¿o barren, but a godly heart can make it a Well; out of which to draw forth water of comfort; either water to clenÅ¿e, and make it a way to Repentance, or water to coole, and make it a way to Patience; or water to moyÅ¿ten, and make it a way of growing in grace; and if the Well happen to bee dry, and afford no water from below; yet the raine Å¿hall fill their pooles, and Å¿upply them with water from above; If naturall forces bee not Å¿ufficient; there Å¿hall bee Å¿upernaturall graces added to
aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them: that though troubles of the world Å¿eeme rubs in the way to bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: yet in truth they are none, they hinder not arriving at the marke we ayme at; they hinder us not from being made Members of Syon; they hinder us not from approaching the preÅ¿ence of God: No my Å¿oule, they are rather helpes; for by this meanes, wee goe from Å¿trength to Å¿trength; from Å¿trength of Patience, to Å¿trength of Hope; from Å¿trength of Hope, to Å¿trength of Faith; from Å¿trength of Faith, to Å¿trength of ViÅ¿ion; and then will be accompliÅ¿hed that which David Å¿peakes here; BleÅ¿Å¿ed is the man, whoÅ¿e Å¿trength is in God; and in whoÅ¿e heart his wayes are.

If my Å¿trength were not in God, I Å¿hould not dare to call upon him, being Lord of HoÅ¿ts: but now that my Å¿trength is in him, and that I know hee is Lord of HoÅ¿ts for me, and not againÅ¿t me: a Shield to me, a Sword onely to my enemies: now I have confidence to Å¿ay: O Lord God of HoÅ¿ts, heare my prayer: give eare, VerÅ¿e 7 O God of Jacob: for as I doubt not but hee will heare me, though he bee Lord of HoÅ¿ts: Å¿o I have much more confidenne, he will give eare unto me, being the God of Jacob: for he hath made a Covenant with Jacob, and with his poÅ¿teritie for ever: that he will be their God, and they Å¿hall be his people: of which number, it is my happineÅ¿Å¿e that I am one; not after the fleÅ¿h, which profiteth nothing, but according
to Faith, the onely thing that makes the true IÅ¿raelite.

But yet what good will it doe me, that God heare my prayer, and give eare unto it, if he be Å¿till averÅ¿e, and turne away his Face? O therefore, Behold, O Lord, our Å¿hield, and looke upon the face of thine anoynted: For I Å¿hall never come to looke upon thy Face, if thou vouchÅ¿afe not firÅ¿t, to looke upon mine: if thou afford me not as well the benefit of thine Eyes, to looke upon me, as the favour of thine Eares to heare me; I Å¿hall be left onely, to a bare expectation, but never come to the happineÅ¿Å¿e of Fruition; but when thou vouchÅ¿afeÅ¿t to looke upon my face; that looke of thine, hath an influence of all true bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, and makes me find what a happineÅ¿Å¿e it is, to have the God of Jacob for my Å¿hield.

But it Å¿hould Å¿eeme that this Prayer belongs onely to David, or at leaÅ¿t to Kings, who like David are the Lords anoynted, and what is it then to us that are private perÅ¿ons? It is true indeed, that Kings are the Lords anoynted in a Å¿peciall manner: but yet every child of God is his anoynted too; for why elÅ¿e is it Å¿aid of ChriÅ¿t, that he was anoynted with the oyle of gladneÅ¿Å¿e, above his fellowes; if it bee not that his fellowes, meaning the children of God, be anoynted too? Anoynted no doubt with the oyle of Grace; but to bee anoynted with the oyle of gladneÅ¿Å¿e, is the very thing I pray for
here: the very thing, that makes mee long Å¿o much for the Courts of the Lord: For one day VerÅ¿e 10 in his courts, is better then a thouÅ¿and: It is not Å¿o much the length of time, as the meaÅ¿ure of joy that makes the bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: Or is it, that one day which Å¿hall never end; as the day is in Gods Courts, is better than a thouÅ¿and which have an end, as all the dayes of this world are. If he had Å¿aid, one day in his Courts, is as good as a thouÅ¿and; though this had beene a mighty odds, yet it had bin but a thouÅ¿and to one, there had at leaÅ¿t beene Å¿ome proportion: but when he Å¿aith; One day in his Courts, is beter than a thouÅ¿and; this Å¿eemes to exceed all poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie of compariÅ¿on, and leaves no place for any proportion. Indeed one day in his Courts, gives Å¿eiÅ¿in of Eternitie, where a ThouÅ¿and that are Å¿pent any where elÅ¿e, are but Å¿teps of Mortalitie. If I be but one day in his Courts, I Å¿hall Å¿ee that which will bee a joy unto mee, all the dayes of my life: where if I be a thouÅ¿and in any other Courts; I Å¿hall Å¿ee nothing but vanitie, and vexation of Å¿pirit, that which will grieve me to thinke of, as often as I remember it. And as it is true in reÅ¿pect of Time; Å¿o it is no leÅ¿Å¿e true in reÅ¿pect of Place: For, I had rather be a doore-keeper in the houÅ¿e of my God, then to dwell in the tents of wickedneÅ¿Å¿e. But is it Å¿uch a diÅ¿paragement to be a Doore-keeper? What was the Angell with the flaming Sword, but the Doore-keeper of ParadiÅ¿e? and is there
not a conceit, that Saint Peter is the Doore-keeper of Heaven? Which though it be a vaine conceit, yet it may leade us to this congruous interpretation of Davids Å¿peech, to conceive as if he Å¿aid, that hee had rather be Saint Peter in the houÅ¿e of God, then be Annas, or Caiphas, in the Court of Herod. Indeed in the Å¿ence that ChriÅ¿t is a Doore; David may well bee content to be a Doore-keeper: and though in Gods HouÅ¿e, there bee many ManÅ¿ions; yet Å¿eeing all of them are glorious, even the Doore-keepers place is not without its glory. But if you thinke the Office to be meane: conÅ¿ider then whoÅ¿e Officer hee is: for even a Doore-keeper is an officer in Gods houÅ¿e; and God never diÅ¿placeth his Officers, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be to advance them to a higher: Where in the Courts of Princes, the greateÅ¿t Officers are often-times diÅ¿placed; turn'd off often with diÅ¿grace. However it be, it Å¿hewes not onely the great glory of Gods HouÅ¿e, but the great humilitie of Davids heart; and that he is not of the ambitious humour of the Mother of Zebedees Å¿onnes, whom no place would Å¿erve for her Å¿onnes, but to have one of them Å¿it at his Right hand, the other at his left. O gracious God, grant me but a Doore-keepers place in thy houÅ¿e, and I will never aÅ¿pire after any higher roome: Not that I deÅ¿ire, to let in, and keepe out whom I pleaÅ¿e, but that I may thereby have liberty to walke in thy houÅ¿e, and to
enjoy thy PreÅ¿ence, in whoÅ¿e preÅ¿ence is the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of Joy for evermore. What are the Tents of wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, but like Caves that have no light, and like Vineyards that have no Fences? and is there any compariÅ¿on to bee made betweene Å¿uch Tents; and the meaneÅ¿t place in the HouÅ¿e of God, where God not onely affordeth Light, but is HimÅ¿elfe the Light; Not onely is a Defendour, but the Defence it Å¿elfe? For the Lord is a Sunne and Å¿hield; the Lord will give grace and glory. I had heard VerÅ¿e 11 before, that In Å¿ole poÅ¿uit Tabernaculum Å¿uum: God hath placed his Tabernacle in the Sunne; But I never knew he was himÅ¿elfe a Sunne till now: but what Sunne? Not the Sunne that is but the child of light, but the Sunne who is the Father of Lights: Not the Sunne that was not, till three dayes after it was light; but the Sunne that was before ever any light was made; Not the Sunne which the Heathen commit Idolatrie in worÅ¿hipping; but the Sunne whom it is Idolatrie not to worÅ¿hip. Oh that the Heathen would all worÅ¿hip this Sunne: it Å¿hould not then be Å¿aid; Plures adorant Solem orientem, quam occidentem: That more worÅ¿hip the Sunne riÅ¿ing, then Å¿etting: for this Sunne once RiÅ¿en, never Å¿ets againe; once Å¿hining, is never any more EcclipÅ¿ed. Oh then vouchÅ¿afe, O God, if thou be a Sunne, to lighten my darkneÅ¿Å¿e; if a Å¿hield, to protect my weakneÅ¿Å¿e: if thou bee a Sunne, warme my
Å¿oule with the beames of Devotion; if a Å¿hield, defend my Å¿oule from the blowes of Temptation: if thou be a Sunne, O Å¿hine upon me, with the light of thy Countenance; if a Shield, O Å¿tand betweene me, and the aÅ¿Å¿aults of Sathan; for alas, O Lord, I am darkneÅ¿Å¿e, and weakneÅ¿Å¿e, the Anvile of temptations, the very Butt of Sathan, if thou bee not a Sunne, and a Shield unto mee. O my Å¿oule, God will doe more then this; Hee will give grace and glory: Grace to be a Shield unto us, and Glory to be a Sunne unto us; Hee will give Grace to prevent us, and Glory to follow us: Grace, to walke uprightly; and Glory, if walking uprightly: Grace for a foundation to Glory, and Glory for a Crowne to Grace: and if theÅ¿e things bee not enough, hee will doe more yet: Doe thou but walke uprightly, and what good things Å¿oever there are in Gods gift, they Å¿hall all be given thee: for No good thing will God with-hold from them that live uprightly.

But how is this true, when God often-times with-holds Riches, and Honours, and health of body from men, though they walke never Å¿o uprightly? We may therefore know, that honours, and riches, and bodily Å¿trength, are none of Gods good things: they are of the number of things indifferent, which God beÅ¿towes promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly upon the juÅ¿t, and unjuÅ¿t, as the raine to fall, and the Sunne to Å¿hine: The good things of God, are chiefly Peace of
conÅ¿cience, and joy in the Holy GhoÅ¿t, in this life; Fruition of Gods PreÅ¿ence, and ViÅ¿ion of his bleÅ¿Å¿ed Face, in the next: and theÅ¿e good things God never beÅ¿towes upon the wicked, never with-holds from the godly; and are all caÅ¿t up in one Å¿umme, where it is Å¿aid, Beati mundo corde, quoniam ipÅ¿i videbunt Deum: BleÅ¿Å¿ed are the pure of Heart, (and Å¿uch are onely they that walke uprightly) for they Å¿hall Å¿ee God. But is walking uprightly Å¿uch a matter with God, that it Å¿hould be Å¿o rewarded? Is it not more pleaÅ¿ing to God to Å¿ee us goe Å¿tooping, then walking upright; Å¿eeing Å¿tooping is the gate of Humilitie; then which, there is nothing to God more pleaÅ¿ing? It is no doubt a hard matter, to Å¿toope, and goe upright, both at once; yet both muÅ¿t be done, and both indeed are done, are done at once by every one that is godly; but when I Å¿ay, they are done both at once, I meane not of the body: I know two Å¿uch poÅ¿tures in the Body both at once, are impoÅ¿Å¿ible: but the Soule can doe it, the Soule can Å¿toope, and goe upright, both at once; for then doth the Soule walke upright before God, when it Å¿toopes in humilitie before God and men.

And what remaines now for David to doe, but to bring in the concluÅ¿ion upon the PremiÅ¿Å¿es, Å¿eeing the Lord of HoÅ¿ts, though his Name be dreadfull, yet his Nature is lovely, Å¿eeing he is a Sunne to cheriÅ¿h, and a Shield to
Defend; Å¿eeing he gives Grace and Glory, and with-holds no good thing from them that walke uprightly; Therefore bleÅ¿Å¿ed are all they that put their truÅ¿t in him.

And what remaines now for us to doe, but to receive this ConcluÅ¿ion of David, as an abÅ¿olute DemonÅ¿tration: and thereupon to walke uprightly, and to put our whole truÅ¿t and confidence in God, through the merits of his Son ChriÅ¿t JeÅ¿us; for then we are Å¿ure, wee are in a Å¿ure way, of attaining to BleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e, to Eternall bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e: that after this, we may leave our wondring, yet continue our Admiring; How amiable are thy Tabernacles, O Lord God of HoÅ¿ts!

div.head: THE HVNDRED AND THIRD PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 BLeÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, O my Å¿oule; and all that is within me, bleÅ¿Å¿e his holy Name.
2 BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, O my Å¿oule; and forget not all his benefits.
3 Who forgiveth all thine iniquities; who healeth all thy infirmities.
4 Who redeemeth thy life from deÅ¿truction; who crowneth thee with loving kindneÅ¿Å¿e, and tender mercies.

5 Who Å¿atisfieth thy mouth with good things;
and renueth thy youth like the Eagles.
6 The Lord executeth RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and Iudgement, for all that are oppreÅ¿Å¿ed.
7 Hee made knowne his wayes unto MoÅ¿es; his Acts to the children of IÅ¿rael.
8 The Lord is mercifull and gracious; Å¿low to anger, and ful of compaÅ¿sion.
9 Hee wil not alwayes chide; neither wil hee keepe his anger for ever.
10 Hee hath not dealt with us after our Å¿innes; nor rewarded us according to our iniquities.
11 For as high as the heaven is above the earth; Å¿o great is his mercy toward them that feare him.
12 As farre as the EaÅ¿t, is from the WeÅ¿t; Å¿o farre hath hee removed our tranÅ¿greÅ¿sions from us.
13 Like as a father pittieth his children; Å¿o the Lord pittieth them that feare him.
14 For he conÅ¿idereth whereof we are framed; he remembers that we are but duÅ¿t.
15 As for man, his dayes are as graÅ¿Å¿e; as a flowre of the field, Å¿o he flouriÅ¿heth.
16 For the wind paÅ¿Å¿eth over it, and it is gone, and the place thereof Å¿hall know it no more.

17 But the mercy of the Lord is from everlaÅ¿ting,
to everlaÅ¿ting, toward them that feare him, and his righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e unto childrens children.
18 To Å¿uch as keepe his Covenant; and remember his Commandements to doe them.
19 The Lord hath prepared his Throne in heaven; and his kingdome ruleth over all.
20 BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord ye his Angels, that excell in Å¿trength: that doe his Commandements; hearkening unto the voyce of his Word.
21 BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, all yee his HoÅ¿ts; Ye MiniÅ¿ters of his, that doe his pleaÅ¿ure.
22 BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord all his workes, in all places of his Dominion: BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, O my Å¿oule.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE CIII. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
BLeÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, O my VerÅ¿e 1 Soule: O how well they are fitted! for what worke Å¿o fit for my Soule as this? Who Å¿o fit for this worke as my Å¿oule? My body, God knowes is groÅ¿Å¿e, and heavie, and very unfit for Å¿o Å¿ublime a worke; No my Å¿oule, it is Thou muÅ¿t doe it; and indeed what haÅ¿t thou elÅ¿e to doe; it is the very worke for which thou wert made, and O that thou wert as fit to doe the worke, as the worke is fit for thee to to doe. But alas, I feare that by comming into this Body of earth, thou art become in a manner earthy, at leaÅ¿t haÅ¿t loÅ¿t a great part of thy
abilities, and wilt never be able to goe thorow with this great worke thy Å¿elfe alone. If to BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord, were no more but to Å¿ay, Lord, Lord, like to them that cryed, The Temple of the Lord, the Temple of the Lord: then my tongue alone would bee Å¿ufficient for it, and I Å¿hould not need to trouble any other about it: but to BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord is an eminent worke, and requires not onely Many, but very able Agents to performe it; and therefore my Soule, when thou goeÅ¿t about it, goe not alone; but, Take with thee, all that is within mee; all the forces in my whole Magazine, whether it be my Heart, or my Spirits; whether my Will, or my Affections; whether my UnderÅ¿tanding, or my Memory; take them all with thee, and BleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord.

And of them all, make uÅ¿e firÅ¿t of my Memorie: VerÅ¿e 2 Forget not all his Benefits: for to remember his Benefits, is indeed a principall part of BleÅ¿Å¿ing him. And the Å¿ooner thou goeÅ¿t about it, the better thou art likely to performe it: for forgetfulneÅ¿Å¿e is a thing, that growes Å¿oone upon us, and nothing Å¿ooner then forgetting of benefits: our Memories, are very apt to retaine Injuries, but very unapt for retaining of Benefits: For as long as we remember a Benefit, we Å¿eeme to Å¿tand upon the rack of an Obligation to requite it: and who is not willing to come off a Rack, by any meanes he can; and then rather by forgetting a Benefit, then by requiting

could expreÅ¿Å¿e a greater pitty, then the name of a Father, ChriÅ¿t would never have taught us to uÅ¿e this Name in making our prayers. And who could be Å¿o fit to make this compariÅ¿on as David, who gave a teÅ¿timonie of it in himÅ¿elfe, by making his moane; O my Å¿onne AbÅ¿olom, my Å¿onne, my Å¿onne AbÅ¿olom; would God I had dyed for thee; O AbÅ¿olom, my Å¿onne, my Å¿onne: that now it Å¿eemes, Gods pitty is matcht; and this example reacheth home, to expreÅ¿Å¿e the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of Gods pitty to the full: No my Å¿oule, it is too Å¿hort yet: for though the pitty of a Father may reach to be willing to dye for his Child, yet Gods pitty reacheth further; not onely to be willing to dye, but to dye indeed: and not onely for a Child, but for his Enemies; for when wee were enemies, even then did ChriÅ¿t very God dye for us: that Gods pitty holds the Å¿upremacie Å¿till, and cannot indeed be matcht; alas, it cannot be expreÅ¿t by any thing that is in man.

But though there may be compariÅ¿on in the tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of their pitties, yet in the abilitie there can bee none; for a Father pitties often-times a child, when he cannot helpe him: but Gods pitty, is alwayes active and powerfull, and never without releeving: that though it be commonly Å¿aid; It is better to be envied, then pittied: yet here it is not Å¿o: but it is a farre happier thing, to be pittied of God, then to be envied of men.

But whom is it that God pitties? onely them that feare him; and indeed Feare is a thing that deÅ¿erves to be pittied: for it makes the joynts to tremble, and puts the Å¿pirits in amazement. But O my Å¿oule, it is not Å¿uch a Feare that is here meant; but this Feare is all one, I may Å¿ay with love, and differs but in the Object: for looking upon Gods JuÅ¿tice wee feare him: and looking upon his Mercy wee love him: although wee love him for his JuÅ¿tice too, and wee feare him for his Mercie too: for as there is Mercie with him, that hee may be feared; Å¿o there is JuÅ¿tice with him that he may be loved.

But why is it, that God pitties them that feare him? Indeed hee hath cauÅ¿e enough to VerÅ¿e 14 pittie them: For hee conÅ¿iders of what wee are framed; Hee remembers that we are but duÅ¿t: and alas, what is there in duÅ¿t to helpe it Å¿elfe, if God in mercy take not pitty upon it? When God lookes downe upon us, and Å¿ees how foule we are growne, whom hee Created cleane: hath he not cauÅ¿e to fall a chiding, and to be angrie, yet when he conÅ¿iders of what we are framed, and that wee are but duÅ¿t; this is Å¿ome cauÅ¿e againe, to make him leave his chiding, and not to keepe his anger for ever; that we may truly Å¿ay, Our miÅ¿eries are our happineÅ¿Å¿e: for if it be our miÅ¿erie, that we are framed of Å¿o meane a matter as DuÅ¿t; It is our happineÅ¿Å¿e, that wee have the meanneÅ¿Å¿e of our matter, for God to
take into his conÅ¿ideration, and perhaps this was it; at leaÅ¿t one circumÅ¿tance that made Å¿o ill for the Angels that fell, that God could find no excuÅ¿e of their Å¿inne in their matter; the more hee conÅ¿idered of what they were framed, the more he found he had cauÅ¿e to bee angrie; and therefore no marvell, if his anger to them continue for ever.

But this is every ones caÅ¿e to bee framed of DuÅ¿t; and why then Å¿hould God pitty Å¿ome, more then others, Å¿eeing they bee equally of DuÅ¿t, All? Is it not, that hee is the leÅ¿Å¿e angrie indeed, for that they are but DuÅ¿t; but yet he pitties them not, for being DuÅ¿t; but for being DuÅ¿t, and fearing him: for if they feare him not, he never pitties them, but lets them goe on in their Pride, at leaÅ¿t in their Å¿ecuritie, and make what they can of their DuÅ¿t: for they reckon upon great matters from their DuÅ¿t, and thinke they can improve it to a great heigth: but alas, what can they make of it, but to come to be graÅ¿Å¿e, at moÅ¿t to get up to be a flowre, a poore fading thing, that whether VerÅ¿e 15 you gather it, or let it grow; whether the Sunne Å¿hine upon it, or the Wind blow upon it, it quickly withers; and once withered, becomes a pittifull Å¿ight to be Å¿eene, a loath Å¿ome thing to be Å¿melt; that where all the grace of it, conÅ¿iÅ¿ted in the two SenÅ¿es, of Å¿ight, and Å¿melling, it is now offenÅ¿ive to both: and is no longer carried in the hand, or worne in the
boÅ¿ome: Alas, it is Å¿carce thought worthy to have a place upon the dunghill. And indeed what could more be lookt for of DuÅ¿t? being Å¿o light a thing as it is; that if the wind but paÅ¿Å¿e over it; if you but blow upon it, it is preÅ¿ently Å¿cattered and gone; and the place where it was, will know it no more. And Å¿uch is Man: his flouriÅ¿hing is but as a Flowre, as quickly withered as a Flowre, and as Å¿oone cropt off from his Å¿talke as a Flowre: and alas, what good is in a flouriÅ¿hing, that ends in a withering? What happineÅ¿Å¿e in pleaÅ¿ures that have no continuance? O my Å¿oule, if thou wert thy Å¿elfe a tranÅ¿itorie thing, and wert not to continue; thou mightÅ¿t juÅ¿tly then looke after tranÅ¿itorie pleaÅ¿ures, and Å¿uch as have no continuance: but Å¿eeing thou art a Å¿ubÅ¿tance perpetuall, and immortall: O therefore looke after pleaÅ¿ures like thy Å¿elfe; pleaÅ¿ures that may laÅ¿t, and never come to the laÅ¿t, that may laÅ¿t and be durable: and not leave thee to the miÅ¿erie of Fuit Ilium, & ingens gloria teucrorum: for FuiÅ¿Å¿e foelicem miÅ¿errimum eÅ¿t: To have beene happy, and not to bee; to have flouriÅ¿hed, and now to bee withered, is the greateÅ¿t miÅ¿erie in the world. And the greater, for that once pluckt off from his Å¿talke; Once taken from the Earth, the Earth will never know him any more; Alas, it will Å¿carce take notice, that ever Å¿uch a one there was; and the VerÅ¿e 16 notice it takes, but in Å¿pecie neither; not in
Individuo; Å¿ome perhaps as of a man; None, as of this man: or rather, Å¿ome, as of a Name; None, as of a man. Or is it rather, that Man turned once to DuÅ¿t, his place will know him no more; for how Å¿hould it know one from another, when they are all Å¿o like? How know Dives from Lazarus, when they have both the Å¿ame face? Å¿eeing Death hath but one copie to draw all her pictures by. Or is it rather that Man once turn'd to DuÅ¿t, is blowne about with every wind, from place to place; and what knowes the place, when DuÅ¿t falls upon it; whether it be the DuÅ¿t of a Prince, or of a PeaÅ¿ant; whether of a Man, or of a BeaÅ¿t? And muÅ¿t not Man then bee needes very miÅ¿erable; when Time, and place, the two beÅ¿t helpes of life doe both forÅ¿ake him? for what helpe can hee have of Time, when his dayes are but as GraÅ¿Å¿e? What help of Place, when his place denyes him, and will not know him? But O how vaine a thing is Man, to forget not onely the very matter of which he is made, but the very condition under which hee is made: and Å¿o to forget it, that God muÅ¿t bee faine to remember him of it: but much the vainer, that being remembred of it never Å¿o often, yet hee regards it never the more, but contenting himÅ¿elfe to be fading graÅ¿Å¿e, at moÅ¿t a fading flowre; never Å¿eekes to improve his DuÅ¿t, to that true Å¿olidneÅ¿Å¿e, which nothing but the feare of God
is able to procure, nothing but the pitty in God is able to effect.

But now at laÅ¿t, if neither the DiÅ¿tances of Place, nor the Affection of Nature can make you Å¿ufficiently conceive the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of Gods mercy: then take an expreÅ¿Å¿ing in plaine tearmes; and this will certainly make you conceive it: For his mercy is from everlaÅ¿ting, VerÅ¿e 17 to everlaÅ¿ting, upon them that feare him: It is from everlaÅ¿ting, for it began to be before the Foundations of the world were laid: and it is to everlaÅ¿ting; for it will continue to be, when the Frame of the World Å¿hall bee diÅ¿Å¿olved: that now, O my Å¿oule, there can bee no feare of the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of Gods mercy: all the feare now, is of thine owne feare: for although VerÅ¿e 18 Gods mercy bee Å¿o EverlaÅ¿ting; yet it is Å¿o, but to them that feare him; for if thou feare him not, and keepe not his Commandements, then his mercy to thee, is neither from EverlaÅ¿ting, nor to EverlaÅ¿ting: but if thou feare him, and keepe his Commandements, then his mercy to thee is both: and not onely to Thee, as though Gods mercy were onely a PerÅ¿onall benefit, and Å¿hould end with thy Å¿elfe: but it Å¿hall be continued to thy childrens children; Et natis natorum, & qui naÅ¿centur ab illis: to thy whole PoÅ¿teritie: O my Å¿oule, what an Inheritance is this, to purchaÅ¿e to our children? at leaÅ¿t if it bee not an abÅ¿olute Inheritance; yet it is Å¿o Å¿ure an Entayle, that
nothing but the want of fearing God, can cut it off.

And indeed, why elÅ¿e hath God prepared VerÅ¿e 19 his Throne in Heaven, but to the end the godly may bee aÅ¿Å¿ured, that though they bee now oppreÅ¿Å¿ed on earth; yet thither they Å¿hall come at laÅ¿t, to bee with him in Joy: to bee there in Joy, for having obeyed him: when the wicked Å¿hall bee left behind to bewayle their miÅ¿eries for not obeying him. For though his Throne be prepared onely in Heaven; Yet his kingdome ruleth over all: Over All, both Man, and BeaÅ¿t; both the Godly, and the Wicked; both bleÅ¿Å¿ed Angells, and damned Spirits; and becauÅ¿e his Kingdome ruleth over all, therefore All Å¿hall Å¿erve him, and Å¿hall Å¿erve him indeed with feare, yet there Å¿hall be a difference, for the godly Å¿hall Å¿erve him with feare and joy, where the wicked Å¿hall Å¿erve him with feare and trembling.

And now, Å¿eeing God hath prepared his Throne in heaven; Therefore, O yee his Angells, inhabitants of Heaven, that obey his Commandements by the freedome of your will; Doe you begin firÅ¿t, and prayÅ¿e his Name: for you excell in Å¿trength, and are beÅ¿t able to doe it. And Å¿eeing his Kingdome ruleth overall: Therefore all ye his HoÅ¿ts, his other Creatures that obey his Commandement too, though not by will, yet by inÅ¿tinct: Doe you Å¿econd the Angels in praiÅ¿ing his Name. And
then thou my Å¿oule, that partakeÅ¿t of both the Natures; Doe thou alÅ¿o, and with thee alÅ¿o, the Soules of all the godly joyne with them in his PrayÅ¿es: that Å¿o at leaÅ¿t there may bee a ConÅ¿ort of Three, to BleÅ¿Å¿e and PraiÅ¿e him, who is a Trinitie in Unitie; Three PerÅ¿ons and one God, to be BleÅ¿Å¿ed, and praiÅ¿ed, for ever, and ever; But to be bleÅ¿Å¿ed and praiÅ¿ed, as by all the perÅ¿ons of his Kingdome, Å¿o in all the places of his Dominion: which are Heaven, and Earth, and Hell: a Triplicitie too: for even Hell is a place within his Dominion: And for praiÅ¿ing him in Heaven, the Angells will be Å¿ure enough to looke to that: and for praiÅ¿ing him in Hell, let the wicked and the damned Å¿pirits looke to that at their perill: but for praiÅ¿ing him on Earth; Thou my Å¿oule, and the Å¿oules of all the godly will undertake to doe that, at leaÅ¿t will pray continually to him that Å¿itteth upon the Throne, to be enabled to doe it: and when all theÅ¿e Å¿hall faile, or leÅ¿t they Å¿hould faile, when Heaven and Earth Å¿hall paÅ¿Å¿e away, when Time and Place Å¿hall bee no more: yet his PrayÅ¿e Å¿hall bee continued Å¿till, by his owne Workes, which are his Glory, and his Power; his InfiniteneÅ¿Å¿e, and his Eternitie; but above all, which is above all his Workes, the Workes of his infinite, and EverlaÅ¿ting Mercie.

div.head: THE HVNDRED AND SIXTEENTH PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p: 1 I Love the Lord: becauÅ¿e hee hath heard my voyce, and my Å¿upplication.
2 BecauÅ¿e hee hath inclined his eare unto me; therefore will I call upon him, as long as I live.
3 The Å¿orrowes of death compaÅ¿Å¿ed me; and the paines of hell got hold upon mee: I found trouble and Å¿orrow.
4 Then called I upon the Name of the Lord; O Lord, I beÅ¿eech thee, deliver my Å¿oule.
5 The Lord is gracious, and righteous; yea, our God is mercifull.
6 The Lord preÅ¿erveth the Å¿imple; I was brought low, and he helped me.
7 Returne unto thy reÅ¿t, O my Å¿oule, for the Lord hath dealt bountifully with thee.
8 For thou haÅ¿t delivered my Å¿oule from death, mine eyes from teares, and my feet from falling.
9 I will walke before the Lord in the land of the living.
10 I beleeved, therefore have I Å¿poken; I was greatly afflicted.
11 I Å¿aid in my haÅ¿t; All men are lyars.
12 What Å¿hall I render to the Lord, for all his benefits towards me?
13 I will take the cup of Å¿alvation, and call upon the Name of the Lord.
14 I will pay my vowes unto the Lord; in the preÅ¿ence of all his people.
15 Pretious in the Å¿ight of the Lord, is the death of his Saints.
16 O Lord, truly I am thy Å¿ervant, I am thy Å¿ervant and the Å¿onne of thy hand-maid; thou haÅ¿t looÅ¿ed my bonds.
17 I will offer to thee, the Å¿acrifice of thankÅ¿-giving; and will call upon the Name of the Lord.
18 I will pay my vowes unto the Lord, in the preÅ¿ence of all his people.
19 In the Courts of the Lords HouÅ¿e: in the midÅ¿t of thee, O HieruÅ¿alem; prayÅ¿e yee the Lord.

div.head: MEDITATIONS VPON THE CXVI. PSALME OF DAVID.
div.p:
BUt how can David Å¿ay VerÅ¿e 1 Å¿o peremptorily; I will love the Lord: as though it were in his owne power to love whom he liÅ¿t? Indeed nothing is Å¿o voluntary as love, that it Å¿eemes to be the extremitie of the will: for then wee are Å¿aid to love a thing, when the will is inclined, and violently bent upon it: and yet I know not how, there Å¿eemes nothing more conÅ¿trained then love; for we often-times love a thing, which we would faine wee could forbeare to love; but that we are drawne to love it, by a kind of violence in the object: and therefore David
may well Å¿ay; I will love the Lord: Å¿eeing both the cauÅ¿es of love are here met, a propenÅ¿ion in the Will, and an excellencie in the Object.

Man indeed is naturally a loving Creature, but doth not alwayes place his love aright: his love is then beÅ¿t placed, when it is placed upon the beÅ¿t Object; and what is that beÅ¿t Object, but God? If he place it upon Beauty, that fadeth: If upon Riches, they periÅ¿h: If upon Honour, that vaniÅ¿heth: If upon life, that waÅ¿teth: but all theÅ¿e are in God, not onely in Eminencie, but in Continuance: In him is Beautie that never fadeth: in him Riches that never periÅ¿h; in him Honour that never vaniÅ¿heth; in him life, that never waÅ¿teth; and therfore as the trueÅ¿t object of love, as the deareÅ¿t object of my love; I will love the Lord.

But though all theÅ¿e Eminencies be in God, yet they would bee no cauÅ¿e for man to love him, if they had not a relation to man: for what cauÅ¿e of love? where there can be expected no effects of love: but Å¿eeing there is in them, not onely a Relation, but a PropenÅ¿ion; not onely they are ready to bee imparted, but are imparted with readineÅ¿Å¿e; what man is hee that will forbeare to Å¿ay, that can forbeare to Å¿ay; I love the Lord? And if all men will forbeare to Å¿ay it, yet I will Å¿ay it: For hee hath heard my voyce, and my Å¿upplication. No doubt a juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e, or rather (indeed to a naturall man) the onely cauÅ¿e for loving of
God. For of fearing him, of praiÅ¿ing him, of worÅ¿hipping him, of magnifying him, there are other cauÅ¿es; but of loving him, no cauÅ¿e Å¿o proper as his loving of us: and the Benefits which he beÅ¿towes upon us. For, love is Å¿o reciprocall a thing, that we Å¿hould hardly love God himÅ¿elfe, but for his Love to us; at leaÅ¿t for our opinion of his love to us; and wee Å¿hould hardly have an opinion of his love, if we had not a feeling of his Benefits: For what love can wee thinke is borne us by them, that are able to doe us good, and doe it not? but when we have a feeling of their benefits, and find they doe us good; then wee are eaÅ¿ily perÅ¿waded of their love; and being Å¿o perÅ¿waded, who can chooÅ¿e but Å¿ay, as David doth here; I love the Lord for he hath heard my voyce, and my Å¿upplication?

But doe we love God, but for his Benefits onely? and if it were not for his Benefits, Å¿hould we not love him? Indeed to love God as we ought, is not to love him for ought, but for himÅ¿elfe onely, without any conÅ¿ideration had at all of his Benefits: but Å¿uch lovers wee are of our owne good, that wee Å¿hould Å¿carce love our Å¿elves, but for the good, we are ready to doe our Å¿elves: and if we love God in the like degree, we thinke it perhaps to be love enough for him. But, O my Å¿oule, this is juÅ¿t the Divells love; I meane Å¿uch love, as the Divell thought to be in Job; Doth Job love God
for nought? He hoped he did not, though hee knew he Å¿hould; and therefore was never in quiet, till it might bee tryed; and if hee had found it Å¿o, he would quickly have made Job leave loving of God, and fall to loving of him. But the hedge which God had Å¿et about Job, was not a hedge of proÅ¿peritie as Sathan Å¿uppoÅ¿ed, but a hedge of Grace, and therefore with all his fierie tryalls, hee could never get other words from Job but Å¿uch as theÅ¿e; Shall we receive good at Gods hands, and Å¿hall we not receive evill? Yes, O Lord, though thou kill mee, yet will I love thee: Thus Job did, and thus Å¿hould we doe: but God knowes, there is not Å¿uch a man againe as Job was upon the face of the earth. For alas, wee are commonly but of the ClaÅ¿Å¿is or forme, of which Saint John Å¿peakes; Wee love God, becauÅ¿e God loved us firÅ¿t: and it were well if we would doe but Å¿o: how much Å¿oever Sathan Å¿lights it, and Å¿eekes to diÅ¿grace it. Or is it perhaps, that David Å¿peakes in the curioÅ¿itie of this diÅ¿tinction, that we doe not Amare Deum, but for his Benefits: but wee may Diligere Deum, without any conÅ¿ideration of his Benefits had at all; and in this Å¿enÅ¿e, a naturall man may Amare Deum: but none but the Å¿pirituall man, Diligere Deum. But, O my Å¿oule, doe thou endevour to be of Jobs forme; to love God without diÅ¿tinction; and whether he heare thy voyce, or heare it not; whether he grant thy Å¿upplication, or grant it not, yet
to love him, and to love with Amando, and with Diligendo; and with any another Devotion of love, that can be expreÅ¿Å¿ed, or conceived. For it is indeed no true love of God, if wee love him for any thing, but for himÅ¿elfe; if we love our Å¿elves, but onely for him: as it Å¿eemes both MoÅ¿es, and Saint Paul did, who for the love of God, left all care of themÅ¿elves, and were contented to have beene (if they might have beene) even Anathema's.

But is this Å¿uch a Benefit to us, that GOD heares us? Is his hearing our voyce, Å¿uch an argument of his love? Alas! hee may heare us, and we never the better: hee may heare our voyce, and yet his love to us perhaps but little, for who will not give a man the hearing, though he love him not at all? With men perhaps it may be Å¿o, but not with God; for his hearing is not onely voluntarie, but reÅ¿erved; Non omnibus dormit: his Eares are not open to every ones cry; indeed to heare us, is in God Å¿o great a favour, that he may well be counted his Favourite, whom he vouchÅ¿afes to heare: and the rather, for that his hearing is alwayes operative, and with a purpoÅ¿e of helping; that if he heare my voyce, I may be Å¿ure, he meanes to grant my Å¿upplication; or rather perhaps in Davids manner of expreÅ¿Å¿ing, in Gods manner of proceeding, to heare my voyce, is no leÅ¿Å¿e in effect, then to grant my Å¿upplication.

And now becauÅ¿e hee hath inclined his eare to VerÅ¿e 2
heare me; I will therefore call upon him, as long as I live: that if it be expected I Å¿hould call upon any other; it muÅ¿t bee when I am dead; for as long as I live, I have vowed to call upon God. But will this be well done? May I not in Å¿o doing, doe more then I Å¿hall have thankes for perhaps for my labour? Is this the requitall that God Å¿hall have for his kindneÅ¿Å¿e in hearing me, that now he Å¿hall have a cuÅ¿tomer of me, and never be in quiet, for my continuall running to him, and calling upon him? Doth God get any thing by my calling upon him, that I Å¿hould make it a Vow, as though in calling upon him, I did him a pleaÅ¿ure? O my Soule, that God might indeed have a cuÅ¿tomer of me in praying: although I confeÅ¿Å¿e I Å¿hould not be Å¿o bold to call upon him Å¿o continually, if his owne commanding me, did not make it a Dutie: for hath not God bid me to call upon him when I am in trouble? and is there any time that I am not in trouble, as long as I live in this vale of miÅ¿erie? and then can there be any time as long as I live, that I muÅ¿t not call upon him? For Å¿hall God bid me, and Å¿hall I not doe it? Å¿hall God incline his Eare, and Å¿tand liÅ¿tening to heare, and Å¿hall I hold my peace for the nonce, that he may have nothing to heare? Or Å¿hall I wave calling upon God, who I know both can, and will heare mee; and call upon Å¿ome other, who I know not whether they can or no? Is Prayer worth any thing if
it bee not in Faith? and can there bee Faith, where there is uncertaintie? O my Soule, this is a great Å¿ecret, which we Å¿hould perhaps have never knowne, if God himÅ¿elfe had not revealed it to us: that to call upon him, is not a trouble to him, but a pleaÅ¿ure; not in us a preÅ¿umption, but a dutie: though it be our Å¿uite, yet it is his Å¿ervice: it is indeed both our Å¿uite and Å¿ervice: and though his glory be not the more by it, yet his glory is the more manifeÅ¿ted by it; and as he is a jealous God, Å¿o of nothing Å¿o much as of his glory, his glory hee will not communicate with any other, any thing elÅ¿e perhaps, but not his glory: and this is all the glory hee can have from us, that wee acknowledge our owne weakneÅ¿Å¿e, and his Power; that we call upon him, not onely as one that is able to helpe us, but as the onely One that is able to helpe us, for elÅ¿e we Å¿atisfie not his jealouÅ¿ie: and if it be a true rule in PhiloÅ¿ophie; FruÅ¿tra fit per plura, quod fieri poteÅ¿t per pauciora: It is no leÅ¿Å¿e true in Divinitie: It is in vaine to call upon any other for reliefe but God alone; if God alone be able, and willing to relieve us. Either therefore wee muÅ¿t Å¿ay, that God is not able, or not willing to helpe us; or elÅ¿e confeÅ¿Å¿e it at leaÅ¿t a great vanitie to call for helpe to any other.

But if Gods benefits be the Motive to love him: why are not his afflictions as well a Motive, not to love him? For is there any evill in
the Citie, and God hath not done it? No my Å¿oule, the reaÅ¿on is not like: his benefits are all gratuitous, and come gratis from him: his Afflictions are as it were violent, and come forcibly from him: his Afflictions are puniÅ¿hments, or chaÅ¿tiÅ¿ements duly deÅ¿erved: but his Benefits are not Wages, or Rewards that are juÅ¿tly merited: and therefore we cannot Å¿o juÅ¿tly Å¿ay, that croÅ¿Å¿es and afflictions are caÅ¿t upon us by God, as that they are drawne upon us by our owne Å¿inne: for Å¿orrowes and paines, are as the Ecchoes I may Å¿ay of Å¿inne: and according as this calls, Å¿o they anÅ¿wer: if Å¿innes be but light, there is like to be heard, but a light reflexe of Å¿orrowes; but if they be crying Å¿innes, heynous, and loude: what marvell if the Ecchoes be anÅ¿werable, and that the Å¿orrowes of Death compaÅ¿Å¿e us about, and the paines of Hell take hold upon us?

But if it be doubted, by what meanes afflictions and croÅ¿Å¿es doe happen to us, yet it cannot be doubted by what meanes they muÅ¿t be removed from us: Å¿eeing there is none able to rowle away the Grave-Å¿tone of our Å¿innes, but onely God: and therefore no meanes to remove afflictions, but onely his Mercy: and no meanes of this meanes, but to call upon him. Doe PhyÅ¿itians uÅ¿e to come to a Patient, unleÅ¿Å¿e they be called? and why then Å¿hould wee looke that God the great PhyÅ¿itian of our Å¿oules, Å¿hould come to helpe us, if we call not
upon him? Upon him, O my Å¿oule, and upon no other: for of his Power and Will to helpe me, I cannot doubt, of others I may: For, the VerÅ¿e 3 Å¿orrowes of death compaÅ¿Å¿ed me; and the paines of hell tooke hold upon me; and can I doubt of his power, that hath delivered me from theÅ¿e? Or can I thinke of any other, that could deliver me from theÅ¿e, but onely hee? Could any deliver me from the Å¿orrowes of Death, but hee onely who triumphed over Death? Could any free me from the paines of Hell, but hee onely who put Hell it Å¿elfe to paine, and caÅ¿t Death and Hell into the Lake of fire? and Å¿hall I call upon any other to deliver me, but upon him onely, who I am well aÅ¿Å¿ured is able to deliver me? No my Å¿oule, but to leave no time, for calling upon any other; I will call upon God, as long as I live: Not for a day, or a moneth, but all the dayes of my life; even as long as I live. And how long will that bee? Alas! how long can it be; Å¿eeing the Å¿orrowes of Death have already compaÅ¿Å¿ed me about; and the paines of hell have taken hold upon mee? For what are the Å¿orrowes of Death, but Å¿orrowes like thoÅ¿e of Rachel, that would not be comforted, becauÅ¿e they were not? What are the paines of Hell, but paines cauÅ¿ed by guiltineÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿in that deÅ¿erves Hell? Paines not more in Å¿enÅ¿e of torment, then deÅ¿paire of remedie? What is it for the Å¿orrowes of death to compaÅ¿Å¿e me about, but as it were to beÅ¿iege me? and was
